Now Modi has protected their lives by making law against triple talaq. Today, not only has India's Haj quota increased but visa rules have also been simplified. The government has also allowed women to go to Hajj without a Mahram."

Recalling the religious Haj tourism and its increased quota he said, "Today, not only has India's Haj quota increased but visa rules have also been simplified. The government has also allowed women to go to Hajj without a Mahram."

PM Modi criticising the Samajwadi government while praising the Yogi regime said that "Riots, murders, gang wars, extortion... were the trademark of the Samajwadi Party government, this was their identity and their politics was also run by this."

"UP CM Yogi Aditiyanath has put an end to it. Now the criminals don't dare to disturb the peace of the citizens," he added

PM Modi talking about Pasmanda (OBC) muslim and their condition over the years, he said

"Parties like Congress and SP have always done appeasement politics and have never done anything for the political, social and economic upliftment of Muslims. When I discuss the plight of Pasmanda Muslims, inke baal khade ho jate hai kyuki upar ke logon ne malai khai hai and they have forced the Pasmanda Muslims to live in the same condition."

b'Hyderabad: Chief minister A Revanth Reddy on Saturday said the BJP has hidden agenda of implementing the RSS plan of making India a 'reservation-free country' by conducting a surgical strike on SC, ST and OBC reservations.

The Congress announced it will enhance reservations of various sections, including OBCs as per their population ratio, which would be revealed after the socio-economic caste census in the country if the party is voted to power in the ensuing elections, he said at a media conference here.

"Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah should tell the people of the country that reservations of SCs and STs will not be scrapped and that the OBC quota will be increased as per their population, if the BJP has no hidden agenda of doing away with the reservations," he said.

Revanth also said BRS president K Chandrasekhar should make his stand clear whether he will support scrapping reservations, a hidden agenda of the BJP or fight against it for continuation of the quota. The Congress stand that BRS and BJP have entered into a secret understanding has been vindicated with BRS former minister Ch Malla Reddy openly supporting BJP's Eatala Rajender in Malkajgiri constituency. Even Eatala, party leaders G Kishan Reddy and Bandi Sanjay were not saying that reservations will not be scrapped, he said.

"BRS-BJP secret deal is exposed in the fact that the BRS has not taken action against Malla Reddy. KCR should suspend him from the party if the BRS has not made any secret deal with BJP for getting bail for his daughter K Kavitha in the Delhi liquor scam. I have already said that KCR-led BRS has mortgaged five Lok Sabha seats to the BJP in his attempt to get bail for his daughter," Revanth alleged.

Also, KCR is following the same ideology of BJP on changing the Constitution as he himself talked about it. His silence on BJP's rhetoric on the Constitution indicates their secret pact, the chief minister affirmed.'

b'Hyderabad: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Sunday announced that if the party wins at the national level, it will implement the Telangana model of pro-poor governance, including guarantees and welfare schemes for SCs, STs, OBCs, minorities, and other underprivileged groups, across the country.

"In Telangana, we pledged and are carrying out initiatives such as free bus travel for women, 10 lakh Aarogya Sri free medical treatment in corporate hospitals, 200 units of free electricity, gas cylinders at 500, Indiramma houses, and creating 30,000 jobs within three months of assuming power," he said at public meetings in Nirmal and later at Gadwal on Sunday.He continued, "Likewise, we will implement every promise from the Congress national manifesto at the national level, including conducting a caste census, providing financial aid to women from every poor family, and offering jobs to youth." His remarks about replicating the Telangana model nationwide are noteworthy, given the party's national Lok Sabha election manifesto titled "Panch Nyay," which includes 25 guarantees and follows the Telangana model's six guarantees and Karnataka's earlier five guarantees, both of which helped Congress secure power in those states.

Rahul also urged Adivasis to vote for Congress candidate Athram Suguna from Adilabad. However, Rahul mistakenly stated in Nirmal that the Congress govt in Telangana is already providing 2,500 monthly pension to women as part of a scheme. While this promise is part of the party's Nov 2023 assembly election manifesto, the scheme is yet to be implemented. He was reportedly informed of the actual situation after the meeting and did not repeat the error during his later speech at Gadwal .'

b'NEW DELHI: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Saturday announced that if his party wins the election and comes to power, they will immediately conduct a caste census throughout the country. He also said they will fill 30 lakh government jobs and start apprenticeships for young people.

Addressing an election rally in a village in Bastar district, Chhattisgarh, Rahul Gandhi characterised the upcoming Lok Sabha elections as a battle between two ideologies.He framed it as a contest between those striving to safeguard the Constitution and those intent on undermining it.

"Fight between two ideologies in Lok Sabha polls; between those seeking to protect Constitution and those out to destroy it," he said.

He further took aim at the Modi-led government, claiming that President Droupadi Murmu was stopped from participating in the Ayodhya Ram temple consecration ceremony due to her tribal identity.

"BJP and RSS have been attacking religion, ideology and history of tribals," Wayanad MP added.

"Modi ji has been trying to change the word 'adivasi'. We call you (tribals) adivasi, but they use the term 'vanvasi'. There is a huge difference between vanvasi and adivasi terms'," he said.

Rahul Gandhi explained that 'adivasi' means tribal people have rights to water, forests, and land, while 'vanvasi' refers to those who live in the jungle.

He accused the BJP and RSS of attacking tribal religion, beliefs, and history. He also criticized the BJP for giving tribal lands to rich people.

Gandhi also claimed that under PM Modi, 22 rich businessmen earned equal to that of 70 crore Indians.

b'SP will end 'Agnipath' scheme, introduce caste-based census by 2025: Akhilesh Yadav while unveiling party manifesto

NEW DELHI: Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav unveiled the party's manifesto on Wednesday, pledging to make a caste-based census by 2025, just a few days ahead of the Lok Sabha elections.

SP Chief Yadav disclosed a 20-page vision document titled 'Hamara Adhikar' at the party headquarters.Like Congress, this party's manifesto also vowed to terminate the Agnipath scheme and implement regular recruitment in the armed forces. Yadav also promised that by 2025, all the government vacancies for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Backward Classes would be filled.

Speaking at a press conference, the SP chief added that if elected, the party would ensure Minimum Support Price (MSP) on all crops under the Swaminathan formula.

"We have named our vision document as 'Janta Ka Maang Patra - Humara Adhikar'. The main demands in this vision document are - the right to protect the constitution, the right to protect democracy, the right to freedom of media, and the right to social justice... the right to social justice is needed for the development of the country. Inclusive development isn't possible without the caste census. Caste census is the axis of development of the country," Yadav said.

The party also pledged to discontinue the Agnipath scheme and enforce regular recruitment in the armed forces.

"The vision document says - the caste census shouldn't be delayed. We will conduct a caste census by 2025, and based on that, justice and participation for all will be ensured by 2029. Legal guarantee to MSP to the farmers on all crops and that too is to be calculated based on the Swaminathan formula. Old Pension Scheme (OPS) will be launched for everyone including paramilitary personnel. Agniveer policy will be put to an end and again the regular recruitments will be done in the armed forces," the SP supremo said.

The SP and the Congress, both members of the opposition INDIA bloc, are contesting the polls in Uttar Pradesh as allies.

b'NEW DELHI: He said an X-ray of society - a national headcount to determine the socio-economic status of marginalised sections - is "now my life's mission".

The Gandhi scion accused Modi of duplicity, saying the PM told the country in 2014 that he was an OBC but when the issue of "caste census" came up, the PM started claiming there were no castes in India, except "rich" and "poor".Warning that "the entire BJP movement's mission is to erase the history" of 90% population, he said the SC/ST/OBCs are being invisibilised from the country's past including the freedom struggle, and their real history has to be planted afresh.

"I am not interested in caste, but am interested in 'nyay'. In India, 90% are facing terrible injustice and I didn't even say that we will take any action. I just said let's find out how much injustice is happening. What is objectionable about it?" Rahul asked, adding, "but look at the media and Modi. As I used the word X-ray, everyone started saying this is an attempt to divide the country. How will an X-ray divide? All patriots should like this."

The speech at "samajik nyay sammelan" organised by Samruddha Bharat Foundation upped the party's stakes in its recently crafted muscular social justice policy. Rahul posited "caste census" at the heart of the Congress agenda and, in the same breath, suggested that the party's tilt towards SC/ST/OBCs is behind the fresh BJP hostility towards Congress. While he did not touch upon the PM's claims linking Congress to "redistribution of wealth", his "I have not even suggested any action but ..." remark appeared a bid to pit social justice against PM's communal pitch in the ongoing Lok Sabha battle.

Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge echoed Rahul by alleging that "BJP poses the biggest danger to SC/ST/OBC/women/minorities" with its "threat to end reservation".

Continuing the arguments he has proffered in recent times, Rahul said the mass media has negligible participation of SC/ST/OBCs, which results in anything good for the latter being dubbed as "non serious or divisive". He said the media used to call him "non serious" which rendered the causes he espoused- Land Acquisition Act, Niyamgiri protests, Bhatta Parsaul, NREGA - "non serious", while "Amitabh Bachchan, Aishwarya Rai and Virat Kohli became serious". He said barely 100 judges out of 650 in the high courts are from 90% population, and most do not manage to reach the apex judiciary, while 200 biggest corporations are neither owned by SC/ST/OBC nor have them in the top management.'

b'BHOPAL: Campaigning for the third phase of Lok Sabha polls for nine seats in Madhya Pradesh, which will decide the political future of three bigwigs- Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Union minister Jyotiraditya Scindia, and Digvijaya Singh, ended on Sunday evening. More than 1.77 crore voters will decide the fate of 127 candidates in the fray amid intense campaigning by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Union Home Minister Amit Shah from the BJP, and Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra from Congress.

The constituencies which will vote on Tuesday include Morena, Bhind (SC-reserved), Gwalior, Guna, Sagar, Vidisha, Bhopal, Rajgarh and Betul (ST-reserved) constituencies.

Voting for the third phase will be held from 7 am to 6 pm across 20,456 polling stations, an official said.

At stake is the political future of BJP leader and Union minister Jyotiraditya Scindia, seeking to reclaim the home turf Guna which he lost in 2019 when he was in Congress.

BJP veteran and former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan is contesting from Vidisha constituency, a saffron fortress which he had represented multiple times in Lok Sabha in the past, after almost 17 years, facing Congress candidate Pratap Bhanu Sharma.

In Rajgarh, Congress veteran and former chief minister Digvijaya Singh, 77, seeks to reclaim the lost legacy, marking his return to the Lok Sabha electoral contest after more than 30 years. His challenger is two-time BJP MP Rodmal Nagar.

The BJP is hoping for a clean sweep in Madhya Pradesh, which sends 29 members to Lok Sabha.

In 2019, the BJP missed whitewashing Congress by a whisker in Chhindwara constituency, the only saving grace for Congress which managed to retain it on the charisma of party veteran Kamal Nath. His son Nakul Nath won the seat last time.

PM Modi and Shah led the high-voltage campaign for BJP wherein they targeted Congress over multiple issues, ranging from quotas to tackling terrorism, and inheritance tax.

Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra set the poll narrative around social justice and raised issues such as unemployment, injustice to farmers, and alleged favourable treatment to select businessmen to target the PM.

Modi also led a roadshow in Bhopal on April 24.

He targeted Congress over wealth redistribution and inheritance tax issues as Rahul Gandhi reiterated Congress' commitment to conduct a caste census and economic survey if voted to power.

In high-stake Guna, where votes of the Yadav community can tilt scales, Scindia is facing Yadvendra Singh Yadav of Congress.

In 2019, Scindia, who was then the Congress candidate, lost the Scindia family bastion to BJP's KP Yadav.

The scion of the erstwhile royal family of Gwalior, Scindia quit the Congress in 2020 and joined the BJP.

Chouhan looks comfortably placed in Vidisha but the contest in Rajgarh may be a close one.

Digvijaya Singh won from Rajgarh in 1984 and 1991 but lost in 1989. He became the chief minister of Madhya Pradesh in 1993.

Union minister Rajnath Singh, Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath, BJP president J P Nadda, and MP CM Mohan Yadav, among others, addressed rallies to drum up support for the party candidates.

For the Congress, former Rajasthan chief minister Ashok Gehlot and ex-Union minister Sachin Pilot addressed public meetings.

Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) supremo Mayawati also addressed a rally in Morena to cobble up support for her party candidates in the Gwalior and Chambal region.

At a rally held in Morena, Modi had claimed that then Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi abolished the inheritance tax apparently to save the money, which he was supposed to get after Indira Gandhi's death, from going to the government.

In an emotional reply, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra hit back at the PM, saying her father inherited "martyrdom" and not wealth from Indira Gandhi, who was assassinated.

Of the total 29 seats in Madhya Pradesh, polling for 12 seats concluded in two phases on April 19 and 26.

The remaining eight seats will go to polls in the fourth phase on May 13.'

b'NEW DELHI: Advocate Prashant Bhushan on Friday expressed support for inheritance tax asking Congress to be on the "front foot on Sam Pitroda's remarks" on the same, adding that every rich country has this tax.

He further said that the BJP government has been opposing this tax "because it is tied to Arabpatis like Adani/Ambani whose children inherit lakhs of crores of their parents".

In a post on X, Prahsnat Bhushan wrote, "Congress Party should be on the front foot on Sam Pitroda's remarks on inheritance tax. This tax will be levied only on crorepatis, not on common people. The money would be used for development & funding employment. Every rich country has this tax."

"BJP is opposing this because it is tied to Arabpatis like Adani/Ambani whose children inherit lakhs of crores of their parents", he added.

This comes after Congress distanced itself from Sam Pitroda's remarks on inheritance tax.

Supporting the idea, he had said in an interview, "Nothing wrong in accumulating wealth but to what point? Let me tell you, in America there's an inheritance tax. So, if let's say one has $100 million worth of wealth, and when he dies he can transfer probably 45% to his children, 55% is grabbed by govt."

"If somebody is worth $10 billion and dies his children get $10 billion. The public gets nothing. So these are the kinds of issues that people will have to debate and discuss," he added.

The Congress was quick to distance itself from Pitroda's remarks.

"Sam Pitroda expresses his views on issues that he considers important, very freely. On this particular issue also he is not reflecting the official position of the Congress," Jairam Ramesh said.

Meanwhile, PM Modi has been relentless with his attacks against the Congress over its manifesto promise of a "nation-wide socio-economic and caste census." PM Modi has accused the grand-old party of having "plans to redistribute wealth".

b"Hyderabad: With reservations becoming a major issue in the 2024 Lok Sabha elections, Backward Classes (BC) aspirants fielded by BJP, BRS and Congress are keeping their fingers crossed over the support they will get from their community in the polling to be held on May 13. BCs comprise over 50% of the population in Telangana, according to various estimates.

Bandi Sanjay Kumar, Eatala Rajender, Dharmapuri Arvind, BB Patil, B Narsaiah Goud, Suresh Kumar Shetkar, T Padma Rao Goud, Nilam Madhu Mudiraj, Kasani Gnaneshwar and G Anil Kumar, who belong to different BC communities, are facing formidable candidates, either from their own communities or other castes.

Political observers said though it has been a divided vote bank of BCs over the years in the state, the issue of removing the 50% cap on quota to enhance the reservations for BCs in proportion to their population and conducting a caste census have the potential to make an impact on the electoral prospects of parties and the candidates.

Though caste equations have always played a crucial role in the elections, the 2024 Lok Sabha polls have assumed significance due to the reservation issue and nothing can be said for sure as to which party would be able to garner more BC votes, said the political observers.

A majority of BCs had sailed with BRS in the 2018 assembly polls. Congress had managed to win only 19 seats, while BJP had lost deposits in 100 constituencies. However, the stunning victory of BJP from four Lok Sabha constituencies in 2019, including two BC candidates, and three by Congress (all three Reddys) as against nine by BRS, revealed that the BC vote bank was divided between the three principal parties in various constituencies in the 2019 general election.

In the 2023 assembly polls, Congress had won 64 seats and could not have done it without the support of BCs, in addition to voters from other communities. This means that a majority of BC voters in rural areas shifted their support from BRS to Congress in the 2023 polls.

For the May 13 election, BJP MP from Karimnagar Bandi Sanjay is facing two candidates from the influential Velama community in Karimnagar district, V Rajender Rao of Congress and ex-MP B Vinod Kumar of BRS. BJP MP from Nizamabad Dharmapuri Arvind, who defeated K Kavitha of BRS in 2019, is pitted against MLC T Jeevan Reddy of Congress and a BC leader and ex-MLA Bajireddy Goverdhan of BRS.

BJP strongman Eatala Rajender has entered the electoral from India's largest constituency in terms of voters, Malkajgiri. This is the first Lok Sabha election he is contesting and he is facing a challenge from two Reddy candidates, Patnam Suneetha Mahender Reddy and Ragidi Laxma Reddy.

In Zahirabad LS constituency, former MP Suresh Shetkar, sitting MP BB Patil and G Anil Kumar fielded by three parties are from the BC community. Nilam Madhu of Congress from Medak, B Narsaiah Goud of BJP from Bhongir, T Padma Rao Goud of BRS in Secunderabad, Kasani Gnaneshwar of BRS in Chevella are all from BC community and face formidable Reddy and other community candidates in their respective constituencies."

b'What did Pitroda say?

He backed the idea of an inheritance tax and cited the example of the US. "Nothing wrong in accumulating wealth but to what point? Let me tell you, in America there's an inheritance tax. So, if let's say one has $100 million worth of wealth, and when he dies he can transfer probably 45% to his children, 55% is grabbed by govt. Now that's an interesting law.It says you, in your generation made wealth, and you are leaving now, you must leave your wealth for the public - not all of it, half of it, which to me sounds fair. In India you don't have that. If somebody is worth $10 billion and dies his children get $10 billion. The public gets nothing. So these are the kinds of issues that people will have to debate and discuss."

Why the controversy?

Pitroda's comments on inheritance tax come against the backdrop of the Congress manifesto talking about addressing "growing inequality of wealth and income through suitable changes in policies" and Rahul Gandhi's speeches pushing for economic and institutional surveys, along with caste census. BJP has cited Rahul's speeches to claim that the surveys would be a prelude to "redistribution" of wealth.

What is inheritance tax?

This is a tax which is levied on property inherited when a person dies. According to Tax Foundation, a think tank on taxation, estate and inheritance taxes are broadly similar because both are generally triggered by death. Estate taxes are levied on the net value of property owned by a deceased person on the date of death. In contrast, inheritance taxes are levied on the recipients of the property, according to the foundation's definition.

Tackling inequality...

Inheritance tax has in some cases been justified to ensure "equality of opportunity". An OECD paper says that by breaking down the concentration of wealth and correcting for factors that are beyond the recipients' control, inheritance and gift taxation can contribute to levelling the playing field across individuals, and thereby increase equality of opportunity and improve social mobility. It cites Thomas Piketty, Saez and Zucman, who have argued that from a meritocratic perspective, inherited wealth should be taxed at higher rates than earned income and self-made wealth. There is an argument against the tax and critics in the US say scrapping it would help raise investments, create jobs and help in expansion of the economy.

What is the global scene?

Several advanced countries, including the US, UK, Japan, France, and Finland, have inheritance tax ranging from 7% to 55%. Since 2000, 11 countries and two tax jurisdictions have scrapped estate or inheritance tax, according to Tax Foundation data. US prez Joe Biden has backed increasing the inheritance tax rate to 61%.

Did India have inheritance tax?

India did have an inheritance tax, and levied a peak rate of 85% estate duty, which was abolished in 1985. Death of a property owner triggered the liability on estate duty. According to tax consulting firm Taxmann, 'property' was defined in the broadest possible terms and included all movable and immovable assets, interest in expectancy, interest in co-parcenary property (joint heirship), debt or enforceable right, etc. "The liability on estate duty was cast on the recipient of the estate who was to file a return of estate received based on which the competent authority would complete an assessment. In case an asset was inherited jointly, a joint return was required to be filed," according to Taxmann.

Several measures to bring social equity have been imposed in the country, including gift tax, wealth tax and estate duty. Wealth tax was scrapped in 2015, while gift tax was withdrawn in 1998 but reintroduced in 2004, levying income tax on gifts to relatives. There was speculation in 2020 that the Union Budget may bring back estate duty. In 2014, the then junior finance minister Jayant Sinha had backed the idea of bringing inheritance tax but it did not move beyond the idea stage.'

b'NAGPUR: Rahul Gandhi on Saturday launched his Maharashtra campaign from Sakoli (Bhandara), where he promised to launch a caste census and scrap the Agniveer policy the day the INDIA bloc is voted to office. He accused PM Modi of crony capitalism and alleged that industrialist Gautam Adani benefited the most from the current dispensation.

After Rahul, the Congress campaign in Maharashtra will be taken forward by party president Mallikarjun Kharge, who will address a rally in Nagpur on April 14 and Priyanka Gandhi will speak in Chandrapur on April 15.

Rahul said a caste census will be the first step to correct inequalities. "When you break a bone, the doctor orders an X-ray so that proper treatment is done. Similarly, we will do a caste census and understand how many people belong to the underprivileged category and whether they have proper representation in the system," he said.

He said once caste census is complete, "the truth will come out". "You are being fooled and this census will clarify your doubts. Modi may keep saying his govt is for OBCs, but that's not the case. Their govt is not of OBCs, Dalits or any underprivileged person," he said.

Most of Vidarbha has a sizeable OBC population, which can swing elections either way. The Bhandara-Gondia Lok Sabha constituency is a straight fight between Congress and BJP, where both have fielded OBC candidates. BJP's Sunil Mendhe is sitting MP whereas Congress's Prashant Padole is making his debut in parliamentary polls.

Rahul said even in govt, representation of OBCs and other underprivileged communities is less. "For every Rs 100 govt spends, those officials who come from underprivileged communities have a say in only Rs 6.90," he said. "PM Modi sticks to his OBC rant, but what has he done for them?" he asked.

He alleged even Prez Draupadi Murmu had to face discrimination. "During the Ram temple (consecration) event at Ayodhya, the President was not allowed inside because she is a Dalit," he alleged.

On his nationwide yatra, Rahul said he met people from different walks of life who gave inputs for the party's manifesto. "I asked them what the biggest issue was, and they all said unemployment. When I spoke to farmers it was about loan burden as well as not getting proper MSP for their produce. Farmers asked why govt is waiving loans for corporates only," he said.

He said Modi was distracting people from real problems. "His speeches have just one purpose, to distract you. Nothing else. And Adani's job is to take money from you," he added. Rahul said the country's wealth has been concentrated in just 22 people, not 70 crore citizens. "Earlier Mumbai airport was being operated by some other entity. They faced action from central agencies and Adani bagged control of the busiest airport. Modi is working for a corporate and his name is Adani. He now has (operates) airports, ports and mines," he said. He slammed the govt's handling of Covid and alleged the media did not cover it at all.'

b'Gurgaon: Former chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar hit out at Congress on Monday, saying the party was finding it difficult to name candidates for 10 parliamentary seats in the state.

Khattar arrived in the city to promote BJP's national manifesto -- Sankalp Patra -- which was unveiled by PM Modi on Sunday.

Comparing the poll preparedness of both parties, Khattar said while BJP began reaching out to voters in March itself, Congress was yet to come up with names of nominees.

"This shows no one is ready to contest on a Congress ticket. We will win all 10 Lok Sabha seats this time too, and with a much bigger margin," the former CM said. In 2019, too, BJP had won all 10 seats.

In Haryana, Congress is fighting the polls in alliance with AAP, with the former contesting from nine of 10 seats. While AAP has already named former Rajya Sabha member and state party chief Sushil Gupta from Kurukshetra, the Congress list is awaited, raising questions about internal bickering.

Interestingly, six of 10 candidates that BJP has named this year were associated with Congress earlier. Asked about the recent switchovers, Khattar said "it isn't uncommon for people to join BJP from various political backgrounds".

The senior BJP leader also criticised Congress's manifesto, which promised to conduct a caste census. He accused the rival party of dividing the society on caste lines and heaped praise on BJP for coming up with just four categories for the development of people -- the youth, women, the poor and farmers.

"BJP govts have served all segments of society equally, without any discrimination whatsoever," he added.

Khattar said BJP's campaign would gain momentum after opposition parties announced their candidates. Jannayak Janta Party (JJP), which was in alliance with BJP until a few weeks ago, has said it will contest in all 10 seats. Indian National Lok Dal (INLD) is also in the process of declaring its candidates, party sources said.

Told about Khattar's claims, Ajay Singh Yadav - national president of Congress's OBC cell - said, "BJP is facing a stiff opposition from people this time. That is why they are making such false claims."

All 10 seats of Haryana will vote in the sixth phase on May 25.'

b'RAIPUR: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is out to change the definition of 'Adivasi' and BJP and RSS are attacking Adivasi religion, beliefs and traditions, Congress leader Rahul Gandhi said in a campaign meeting in tribal Bastar on Saturday.

Congress will conduct a caste-based census as soon as it forms the govt and described the 2024 Lok Sabha elections as a "fight between two ideologies" -- those seeking to protect the Constitution and those out to destroy it.

Voters have to choose between Congress, which is "saving the Constitution and democracy", and PM Modi and RSS, "who are attacking the constitution to destroy it", Rahul said at a poll rally for Congress candidate Kawasi Lakhma, a former minister.

Alleging that Prime Minister Modi and BJP deliberately use the word 'vanvasi' for tribals, instead of 'Adivasi', with the "intention of taking away their rights to jal-jungle-jameen".

"There is a huge difference in the meaning of 'Adivasi' and 'vanvasi'. 'Adivasis' have been living in jungles even before the nation came into existence and are the real owners of the land and have first rights over jal, jungle, jameen. Those who call you 'vanvasi', they don't believe you were part of any rights in this country and they simply call you forest dwellers, and don't own any forest rights," the former AICC chief said.

"We brought about PESA, tribal bill, land acquisition bill, MNREGA and got you your land back, but BJP and RSS people attack your religion, ideology and history," Rahul said, alleging that BJP did not invite President Droupadi Murmu to the for consecration of Ram Lalla in Ayodhya because she is a tribal.

"Under PM Modi's rule, only 22-25 businessmen accumulated wealth equal to that of 70 crore Indians and they are supported round the clock by Modi," he alleged.

"Ask anyone about the issues in this country, they would say unemployment and inflation. Now, the question arises, if BJP and Modi work for the rich people and give away the wealth of farmers, labourers, tribals and Dalits to a section of people, what will Congress do once it comes to power? We are going to fill 30 lakh govt vacancies soon after forming the govt and address the problem of unemployment. An apprenticeship right will be given for a year to educated youths having a degree or diploma at PSUs, govt offices and private companies. The youths will then be absorbed, based on their performance," the Congress leader said adding, this will be a way to enter the job market and these youths will get Rs 1 lakh a year in their account.

The poor and jobless face the highest insecurity as they don't even get medical facilities, so Congress has decided that govt offices and PSUs will end the contract culture and all the jobs provided will be permanent, the Wayanad MP said.

"Modi ji has waived loans worth Rs 16 lakh crore of 22-25 people. This money belonged to people who worked under MNREGA. But he (PM Modi) can't give relief to farmers? Congress will do that, and farmers in this country will get the proper price for their hard work along with legal guarantee," Rahul said.

"We also look forward to changing the lives of women under Mahalaxmi Yojana that will transfer Rs 8,500 to the account of one woman member of a family every month, and steadily the poor will come out of poverty line. Women will also be given reservation," Rahul said.

Arguing that there was an imbalance between Dalits, tribals, minorities, OBCs and other communities, Rahul said the only solution to this was to conduct a caste census. "This will lead to real development. Congress will conduct a caste census soon after forming the govt," he said.'

b'Hyderabad: Political parties that are going all out to woo Backward Castes, who constitute 52% in the state, are now focusing on major five castes, especially Mudiraj voters.

Among the BC communities, Mudirajs constitute 16% in the state and their population is estimated to be around 45 lakh to 50 lakh according to Mudiraj community leaders and Samagra Kutumba Survey (SKS) conducted by Telangana govt in 2014.

Congress, BRS and BJP are now roping in various BC caste organisations such as Mudirajs, Gouds, Yadavs, Padmashalis and Kapus, which are the major castes in terms of their population among the BCs to enlist their support.

In this Lok Sabha elections, Congress, BRS and BJP have given one ticket each to Mudiraj community in the 17 Lok Sabha constituency. BRS fielded Kasani Gnaneshwar, former MLC and president of Mudiraj Mahasabha, from Chevella while Congress gave ticket to Neelam Madhu from Medak. BJP fielded former minister Eatala Rajender from Malkajgiri.

According to Mudiraj leaders, the community voters are the deciding factor in some of the constituencies. For instance, Parigi has highest number of Mudiraj voters in Chevella and BRS gave the ticket to Gnaneshwar from Chevella keeping in view of presence of more BCs, especially Mudirajs, in the constituency. Gnaneshwar is also trying to rope in BC caste organisations in the elections to campaign for him.

Similarly, Gajwel and Patancheru assembly segments in Medak Lok Sabha seat have more Mudiraj voters. Madhu tried for ticket from BRS and Congress in the 2023 assembly polls from Patancheru but failed. He contested on a BSP ticket. Later, he joined the Congress, which offered him the Medak Lok Sabha ticket. Interestingly, Eatala, who contested from Gajwel on a BJP ticket in the Nov 2023 assembly polls, chose to enter the fray from Gajwel because of huge presence of Mudiraj voters. He, however, lost then.

In Secunderabad, BCs are more in number and the BRS fielded T Padma Rao, a Goud community leader, while Congress gave the ticket to Danam Nagender, a Kapu leader.

To get BCs support, Congress passed a resolution on caste census in the state assembly in the budget session. The BRS too pitched for caste census and demanded a separate ministry of OBCs at the Centre and claimed it had given more tickets to BCs in the LS polls.

The BJP is also trying to woo BCs by claiming that the BJP govt has taken up measures for the welfare of BCs and that PM Narendra Modi himself belongs to BC community.'

b'Nagpur/Amravati: In a valiant move to woo farmers, former Congress president Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday said if voted to power, his party will establish a commission to grant loan waivers to farmers rather than corporates. Addressing a packed rally at Paratwada (Amravati), he accused PM Modi of catering to "needs of 25 billionaires" at the cost of the common man.

Rahul Gandhi said "The rich train their wards in jobs and business through apprenticeship, but poor don't get the same facility. Under the new law, we will offer one-year apprenticeship and job guarantee in either public or private sector or government offices. Participants would also receive a stipend of 1 lakh per year. After one year, India will have the best trained workforce in the world."

Turning his attention to women's welfare, the former Congress president outlined the 'mahalaxmi' scheme, which aims to disburse 1 lakh aid every year to women from poor families directly in their accounts. "In 21st century, men and women work in MGNREGA and both get wages. The woman works for eight hours there and another eight hours at home for which she doesn't get any remuneration. This amount would be offered to her for this work, which is often not recognized. We will also double wages of anganwadi sevikas and Asha workers," he said.

To put money into farmers' pockets, Gandhi said there will be loan waivers for them "rather than for corporates". While promising to establish a permanent commission to recommend loan waivers for farmers as per requirements, Gandhi said "if loans of billionaires are waived, why not of farmers? We do not have any shortage of money."

He said, the Modi-led government was catering to the interests of billionaires, while neglecting the masses. Gandhi said, "Modi administration has prioritized the needs of 22-25 billionaires whose collective wealth equals that of 70 crore Indians. The govt waived Rs 16 lakh crore in loans of these billionaires, but neglected farmers. Still the PM says he is working for the poor."

Sharing the stage with MPCC president Nana Patole along with Wankhade and Congress candidate from Akola, Dr Abhay Patil, MLA Yashomati Thakur and others, Gandhi said 2024 elections were for protection of democracy and the Constitution, which BJP wanted to change.

"It is the first political party in India which has dared to attack the Constitution along with NDA and RSS. It is the voice of backward classes. The Constitution is not just a book, but it is a weapon. Modi diverts your mind to Pakistan or China and is trying to change the Constitution."

Highlighting the lack of representation of marginalized communities in media, corporate, and administrative sectors, Gandhi stressed the need for inclusive governance.

"Modi does not want the poor to get acquainted with their rights through the Constitution. He keeps tribal and poor sections of the society away from limelight. Despite being the first tribal President of the country, Draupadi Murmu was kept away from Ram Temple and Parliament building inaugurations. We are now going to do an X-ray of India through the caste census as the first thing when we come to power. We will then conduct an economic survey and every caste will benefit according to its population. This will change the face of India," said Gandhi.'

b'BENGALURU: Although Lok Sabha elections have concluded in Karnataka, parties have little time to rest since a series of important polls are likely to be scheduled over the next six months.

In fact, the electoral fervour began with assembly elections in April-May last year and with zilla and taluk panchayats elections and Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) polls likely to be scheduled later this year, political functionaries will remain on their toes.

Elections to these local bodies are long overdue and were postponed for many reasons, resulting in a packed schedule this year. Zilla and taluk panchayat (ZP-TP) polls -- an exercise that is perhaps matched only by assembly polls since they will be held across 31 districts and encompass an electorate of about 4 crore -- have been pending since May 2021, while BBMP council polls were originally due in September 2020. They were first disrupted by the pandemic and later reorganization of constituencies.

"Successive govts evaded ZP-TP and BBMP polls," said Tippeswamy, a senior JD(S) functionary. "It appears the time has arrived since the current administration cannot avoid its constitutional duty of conducting elections to these local bodies."

In Jan, the state govt told the high court that it will fulfil all necessary procedures to conduct these elections within a month. The court was hearing a petition filed by the Karnataka State Election Com mission (SEC).

Key processes involve delimitation of constituencies and notification of constituency-wise reservation. SEC has already compiled electoral rolls, with arrangements underway for a final round of revision.

While the delimitation exercise for both ZP-TP constituencies and BBMP wards has been completed, the govt is yet to finalise reservation. In Sept last year, the urban development department reduced BBMP wards from 243 to 225 through a notification. Delimitation for zilla panchayats, comprising 1,101 constituencies, and taluk panchayats (3,621 seats), was carried out in Nov 2023.

Quota conundrum

Priyank Kharge, minister for panchayat raj and rural development, said: "We are not avoiding ZP-TP polls. They will be conducted soon."

Yet, this determination does not mirror action on the ground in terms of finalising reservation. This, despite the govt accepting the Justice K Bhaktavatsala Commission report, which recommends 33% reservation for Other Backward Classes (OBCs) in local bodies. Officials suggest the govt is likely to address this issue in the next cabinet meeting -- when it is also likely to discuss the caste census report submitted by the K Jayaprakash Hegde Commission.

"The state govt has not fulfilled its commitment to the HC regarding reservation. We will petition the court to instruct the govt," said S Basavaraj, SEC commissioner.

Council polls first up

Meanwhile, in June, Karnataka will also witness elections to 17 seats in the legislative council. These elections have been necessitated due to retirements and resignations of members from various constituencies, including teachers', graduates', local bodies, and the legislative assembly.

"Council polls are significant since they can alter party standings. We are confident of securing a majority, as we anticipate winning eight of the 11 seats allocated from the assembly quota," said Saleem Ahmed, Congress chief whip in the council. "We are also optimistic about winning all six seats from teachers' and graduates' constituencies."'

b'Lucknow: CM Yogi Adityanath on Wednesday launched a searing attack on Congress accusing it of hatching a conspiracy to deny reservation rights to OBCs and Dalits through caste census and enforcing a "talibani" mentality that could potentially hit the women.

Yogi categorically whipped up Rangnath Mishra and Sachar committees which were set up during the previous Congress-led UPA regimes, terming them as "malicious attempts" to encroach upon the rights of Dalits and OBCs and giving them to Muslims.

"Rangnath Mishra committee ke madhyam se SC/ST aur OBC varg ke arakshan ko jabran kuch vishesh varg vishesh ko dene ke kutsit prayas hue they. Aur fir Sachar committee ke madhyam se SC/ST ke arakshan mein ghuspaith karke ek hissa Muslim varg ko dene ke kutsit prayas kiye gaye they jiska us samak bhari virodh hua tha... ," Yogi said, while addressing reporters at the state BJP office after inaugurating the media centre.'

b'Hubballi: The Congress party has intensified its campaign for the Dharwad parliamentary constituency. According to the plan, several teams of workers at booth level will go door to door and seek votes for Congress in a couple of days.

After AICC general secretary Randeep Surjewala visited the district, campaign strategies have been chalked out. Surjewala took stock of the activities last Wednesday and guided party workers on intensifying the campaign.

According to sources, Surjewala stressed Guarantees implementation monitoring committees constituted by the state govt constituency-wise to take the new guarantees to every household.In a closed-door meeting, Surjewala directed them to convince people to vote for Congress to implement Yuva Nyay, Nari Nyay, Kisan Nyay, Shramik Nyay, and Hissedari Nyay are the major guarantees announced by the Congress party for the Lok Sabha election.

In each booth, a team of twenty members will be formed, distributing the guarantees pamphlets door-to-door, explaining in detail the guarantees and appealing to people to vote for the Congress party, sources added.

In Nari Nyay, Rs 1 lakh every year for a woman from every poor family; under Yuva Nyay, a stipend of Rs 1 lakh for a year; filling 30 lakh govt vacancies; in Hissedari Nyay; caste census for social and economic equality and also removal of 50% cap on reservation; under Shramik Nyay, Rs 25 lakh medical insurance and Rs 400 daily minimum wage including MGNREGA are the highlights of the new guarantees, sources added.

Vadiraj Kulkarni, member of the Guarantees implementation monitoring committee for the Hubballi-Dharwad East Constituency, said that recently the state govt formed these committees, each comprising 15 members and a chairperson.

Rashid Bholabhai, chairperson of the Guarantees implementation monitoring committee for the Hubballi-Dharwad East constituency, said that in a couple of days, special teams will be formed in each booth of the constituency to inform people how the Congress implemented poll guarantees and also to explain about the new guarantees announced.'

b'HYDERABAD: Mounting his attack on the BJP, Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Sunday alleged that Prime Minister Narendra Modi was against reservations and wanted to take away quotas from the people. Addressing an election rally at Nirmal under Adilabad (ST) Lok Sabha constituency in Telangana, he claimed that the ongoing general elections is taking place between two ideologies in which Congress is trying to safeguard the Constitution, while the BJP-RSS combine wants to end it and people's rights.

"Narendra Modi ji is against reservation. He wants to take away reservations from you. The biggest issue before the country is increasing reservation from 50 per cent," he added.

The Congress has in its manifesto promised that if the party forms the government at the Centre, it will breach the 50 per cent limit and increase the quotas beyond 50 per cent, he said.

BJP leaders also want reservations to end, he claimed.

Alleging that Modi privatised the public sector, Gandhi said the contract system implemented by the BJP-led government amounts to removing reservations.

"We will remove contract systems in government offices and the public sector. Permanent jobs would be available, not temporary jobs," he said.

"Narendra Modi has never said in his speeches till today that he will remove the 50 per cent barrier of reservations," Gandhi said.

He claimed that BJP leaders have told the countrymen that if their party wins elections, they will change and finish the Constitution.

"If the Constitution is finished, reservation will end," he said.

The BJP wants backward classes, dalits, adivasis remain backward, he alleged.

PM Modi waived off loans to the tune of Rs 16 lakh crore of about 22-25 people. "Rs 16 lakh crore means MNREGA money of 24 years, Narendra Modi ji gave to 22 people," he claimed.

The 22 rich people have money equivalent to what 70 crore Indians have. "The Congress is going to change this," he said.

Observing that the Congress government in Telangana implements poll promises like free travel for women in state-run buses, Gandhi said his party, if it comes to power at the Centre, would implement similar 'guarantees' across the country.

He said a list of poor families in the country would be taken up and Rs one lakh per annum would be deposited in the bank account of a woman from every family.

Noting that more than 90 per cent of the population comprises backward classes, adivasis, minorities and the poor in the general category, the Congress leader said they don't have a place in any organisation in the country.

The caste census proposed by the Congress would change the politics of the country because such poor and 90 per cent of people would come to know about their population and share, he said.

"We will make a survey of every organisation in the country. We will find out how much money the backward classes, dalits, adivasis and the poor have. After the caste census, there will be new politics in Telangana and in the country," he said.

The Constitution should be safeguarded and reservations should be increased, Gandhi said.

The incumbent government of the rich should be dislodged from power and the government of the poor, farmers, dalits and others should be installed, he added.'

b'KOLHAPUR: NCP (SCP) chief Sharad Pawar said on Thursday that giving reservations on the basis of religion had not crossed the minds of INDIA bloc politicians, adding that the alliance categorically disapproved of the idea of reservation on the basis of religion.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi, while speaking in a rally in Gujarat on Wednesday, said that under the caste-census, the INDIA bloc would expand the reservation quota and grant reservation to Muslims.The prime minister had said that he would not let that happen so long he was alive, describing it as a dirty game.

Addressing press conference on Thursday in Kolhapur, Pawar said the prime minister was coming up with twisted ideas such as reservation for Muslims, Congress snatching mangalsutra etc, which were not discussed in INDIA bloc meetings nor mentioned in the manifesto.

Pawar said, "The idea of reservation on the basis of religion has never touched our minds. We disapprove the idea totally. If somebody tries, even if Modi tries, we will resist."

On Modi targeting the socio-economic census that the INDIA bloc had proposed to carry out, Pawar said that it would be done to understand where the smaller communities stand, and the picture should come to the fore before the country. "We insist on doing this because we want smaller communities to be brought in the process of development. For that we need to understand their population, where they reside and few more things," said Pawar.

Modi recently accused INDIA alliance, saying that if INDIA alliance does not have any PM face then alliance leaders will plan to change the prime minister every year if it wins. Pawar said that there is no need to worry who will be PM after INDIA wins.

Pawar said, "We have discussed no such thing. I don't know how Modi comes up with such ideas. There was no discussion regarding PM face during INDIA meetings. In 1977, under Jay Prakash Narayan's clarion call, all opposition united to defeat Congress. The opposition parties later sat together and name of Morarji Our role will be to stay strong behind the leader to ensure that the govt remains stable and completes five-year tenure. Modi is day-dreaming about new PM every year, it is in his mind not ours," said Pawar.

When asked whether opposition is trying instil fear in the minds of people over his repeat narrative of 'Modi becoming Putin' (Russia's president) and Modi will change the Constitution to remain in power forever, Pawar said, "His behaviour so far, the decisions taken so far shows that we need to be alert. I will not directly say that he will definitely become Putin like, but leaders and people should be alert."

Pawar said that Sangli remained an exception in the seat-sharing discussion as Shiv Sena (UBT) declared the seat without discussion. "It is just one such decision among 48 Lok Sabha seats. We saw the candidate declared in the evening on television. We started searching who is the candidate what is his contribution. However, we approved the decision after many yes and nos," said Pawar.'

b'PATNA: Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge, who addressed twin election rallies in Katihar and Kishanganj on Friday, accused the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) of propagating the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) agenda in the country and devising ways to destroy the Constitution.

"While Prime Minister Narendra Modi keeps on saying that the Constitution will not be changed, his people are working on 'abki baar, 400 paar' mission.They urge people to give two-thirds majority to BJP to amend the Constitution," Kharge said while addressing a rally at Rajendra Stadium in Katihar in favour of party candidate Tariq Anwar.

Kharge said while the BJP was seeking votes to amend the Constitution and kill democracy, the Congress believed in reaching out to the people with a promise to end their plights.

"Dr Bhim Rao Ambedkar's Constitution, which was adopted by the Constituent Assembly in 1949 and came into force on January 26, 1950, gave voting rights to the people of all sections of society. The BJP people are now trying to push RSS agenda and snatch the voting rights of these people," Kharge alleged.

In Kishanganj, where the Congress has fielded sitting MP Mohd Jawed, Kharge said he did not retire from politics even at the age of 82 just to take on people like Modi who are trying to spoil the country's secular fabric.

The Congress president also poohpoohed Bihar CM Nitish Kumar for his frequent flip-flops. "RJD's Tejashwi Prasad Yadav often says that his 'chacha' was hijacked. I suggest him to let Nitish remain hijacked as he has grown older. There is no need to take him back. Nitish has no ideology. He can ditch anyone for political gains," Kharge said in Katihar.

The Congress president held the NDA govts at the Centre and in state responsible for the plights of the Seemanchal people. "Seemanchal is still considered a backward region. People from the region, once the textile hub of the state, migrate to other places to seek jobs. Nitish remained in power in the state for more than 15 years. What has he done for the Seemanchal region despite being part of the so-called double-engine govt?" Kharge asked.

He highlighted the party's poll manifesto and talked about conducting a nationwide socio-economic and caste census, amending Constitution to raise 50% cap on reservations for SC, ST and OBC communities, launching the Mahalakshmi scheme to provide Rs 1 lakh per year to every poor Indian family and filling nearly 40 lakh vacancies in sanctioned posts at various levels in the central govt.

This was Kharge's first visit to the state after the announcement of Lok Sabha poll schedule. However, no key leader from the INDIA bloc attended Kharge's twin rallies as RJD's Tejashwi Prasad Yadav was busy with his own programmes.

Congress's Tariq Anwar and Mohd Jawed are pitted against JD (U)'s Dulal Chandra Goswami and Mujahid Alam in Katihar and Kishanganj Lok Sabha seats, respectively. Three Seemanchal districts - Kishanganj, Katihar and Purnia - are among the five constituencies in the state where elections will be held in the second phase on April 26. The other two districts going to polls in the second phase are Bhagalpur and Banka.'

b'Hyderabad: Advisor to the Congress govt, Mohammed Ali Shabbir, on Tuesday said Congress manifesto \'Nyay Patra\' assures equitable development for all sections of society with major promises like nationwide socio-economic and caste census, constitutional amendment to raise the 50% cap on reservations for SC, ST and OBC communities and a 10% quota in jobs and educational institutions for economically weaker sections, which will be implemented if the party is voted to power at the national level.\n\nCongress will empower BCs, Dalits, Adivasis, minorities and poorer sections from the OC communities, he said. b'NEW DELHI: BJP on Sunday released its election manifesto, betting big on PM Narendra Modi's credibility as the "man who delivers" and the party's development plank, while dodging the temptation to match promises made by its opponents.

The 'Sankalp Patra' builds on Modi's vision of India becoming a developed country by 2047 to detail the planks of the aspiration - further acceleration of infrastructure creation and upgrade marked by expansion of bullet train network, launch of 'new age' trains and modern airports, construction of more expressways and an ambitious plan to develop the country into a global manufacturing powerhouse.

The bold intent extends to help India emerge as a 'product nation', defence manufacturer, global hub for railway manufacturing, centre for aircraft manufacturing and MRO (Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul) activities, a site of ship building as well as semiconductor, chip manufacturing and bio-manufacturing hubs.

Simultaneously, the party has also tapped into the excitement over the rise in India's global geopolitical heft with enough soft power of its own.

BJP has promised to implement the recommendations of a high-powered panel for simultaneously holding all elections across India. The party has also said it will provide for a common electoral roll for all levels of polls.

Document a play on what BJP sees as a 'confident nation'

The contrast from Congress and other opposition parties is clear, with BJP refusing to play catch up on the populist track and mentioning fiscal prudence as a mantra for economic management. It has kept its distance from caste census, which is seen by many as a popular theme with the majority of the population. It has also held its own against Congress's promise for a legal guarantee for MSP for farm produce, and goes on to talk about incentivising crop diversification.

The 76-page document, with the imprint of Modi writ large all over it, is a play for what BJP views as a confident nation, with new goals to pursue.

On the issue of jobs, it has restricted itself to the promise of creation of quality jobs, skilling, promotion of self-employment through expansion of startups, Mudra and Svanidhi schemes and steps to help vendors, transparent recruitment for govt jobs and the assertion that the govt has speeded up filling of vacancies over the last few years.

The restraint may appear to be a gambit, but seems to reflect an assessment that significant sections have ceased basing their voting preference on freebies offered to them. It also reflects the confidence and self-assuredness that was visible in the bland interim budget earlier this year.

The party is clearly laying store by Modi's track record in fulfilling promises and the manifesto has a full "mission accomplished" section -- from Ram Mandir to Article 370.

But it is not that the party has not tried to reach out to specific sections. The promise to extend Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme to senior citizens of 70 years of all income brackets and seeking to provide essential services at home is one such. The promise of a constituency in Tamil Nadu has led the party to use the manifesto to signal its friendly intent to the state, thus far an indifferent geography amid rising support for the party elsewhere, by a display of reverence for the legendary Thiruvalluvar.

The party has promised to build upon established vote-spinners like Ujjwala gas connection scheme, free ration and subsidised rural housing. Help has been promised also for women and those looking for homes in urban areas.

Of course, the successes already clocked on the core issues -- Ram Mandir and abrogation of 370 and the promise to score one more, on UCC -- is a reminder to Hindutva adherents to reciprocate the favour.'

b'RAIPUR: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi at a poll rally in Maoist affected Bastar region said that his party will conduct caste census as soon as it comes to power and described the Lok Sabha elections as a fight between two ideologies of those seeking to protect the Constitution and those out to destroy it. Alleging that Prime Minister Narendra Modi was trying to change the reference of the word 'Adivasi', Rahul said that Modi and BJP use 'vanvasi' for tribals with intention to take away their rights on jal-jungle-jameen.

Rahul Gandhi's rally was held in support of Congress candidate Kawasi Lakhma contesting from Bastar Lok Sabha seat reserved for Scheduled Tribe.

"There were two ideologies in front of you, one of Congress that's up for saving constitution and democracy and on the other hand Modi, Adani and RSS who are attacking the constitution to destroy it," Rahul said his opening remarks.

He said that there was a huge difference in the meaning of 'adivasi' and 'vanvasi' and 'adivasi' is the group that has been living in jungles even before the nation came into existence and is the real owner and have first rights over jal, jungle, jameen.

"Those who call you (tribals) 'vanvasi' they don't believe you were part of any rights in this country and they simply call you forest dwellers, and don't own any forest rights. WE brought PESA, tribal bill, land acquisition bill, MNREGA and get you your land back but BJP and RSS people attack on your religion, ideology and history," Rahul said adding that BJP did not invite President Droupadi Murmu for inaugural event of Ram temple in Ayodhya just because she is a tribal.

Rahul claimed that under PM Modi's rule, 22-25 businessmen accumulated wealth equal to that of 70 crore Indians and they are supported round the clock by Modi.

"Ask anyone about the issues in this country, they would say unemployment and inflation. Now, the question arises, if BJP and Modi work for the Richie-rich people and give away the wealth of farmer, labourers, tribalsand Dalits to a section of people, what will Congress do once it comes to power? We are going to fill 30 lakh govt vacancies soon after coming to power and address the problem of unemployment. An apprenticeship right will be given for a year to educated youths having degree or diploma at PSUs, govt offices and private companies. The youths will then be absorbed based on their performance," the Congress leader said adding, this will be a way to enter the job market and these youths will get Rs 1 lakh annual in their account.

The poor face the highest insecurity in jobs as they get no facility of medical etc, hence, Congress has decided that govt offices, PSUs will end the contract culture and jobs provided will be permanent.

"Modi ji has waved off loans of 22-25 people worth Rs 16 lakh crore, which belonged to people worked under MNREGA. But he can't give relief to farmers? Congress will do that and farmers in this country will get proper price for their hardwork along with legal guarantee. We also look forward to change lives of women under Mahalaxmi yojana that will transfer Rs 8500 to accounts of one woman member of a family every month and steadily poor will come out of poverty line. Women will also be given reservation," Rahul said.

Pointing out there was a disbalance between Dalits, tribals, minorities, OBCs and others, Rahul said the only solution to this was conducting a caste census which will lead to real development. He said that Congress will conduct the caste census soon after coming to power.'

b'Hyderabad: Deputy chief minister Bhatti Vikramarka on Tuesday said continuation of democracy, Constitution and reservations are in danger as the BJP is conspiring to alter the Constitution and do away with reservations.

b'NEW DELHI: Expressing alarm at a three-year delay in conducting the 2021 decadal census, Congress on Thursday alleged Modi govt of wanting to scrap SC/ST reservations and said that is the intent behind the unprecedented postponement in holding the national headcount.

Congress also accused PM Modi of lying, saying 'inheritance tax' is not on the party agenda and it was Rajiv Gandhi who ended the said tax in 1985, while BJP netas, led by Arun Jaitley and Jayant Sinha, had advocated it in Modi govt.Speaking to reporters, AICC spokesman Jairam Ramesh said PM Modi's policy is "asatyamev jayate", which is making him speak lies about Congress in his election speeches.

At the same time, he said BJP has neither published the caste data collected under Socio-Economic Caste Census conducted by UPA govt, nor has it ordered a fresh SECC which should be done every ten years.

On Modi's "lies about wealth redistribution" and "inheritance tax" and his "communal" tone, Ramesh said the PM wants to "drag Congress to the pitch prepared by Jay Shah and others", but Congress will stick to its positive agenda of jobs, economy, prices, saving Constitution and democracy, and social welfare.

On PM Modi's allegation of Congress eyeing gold and "mangalsutras" of women, Ramesh said a Reserve Bank of India (RBI) report says that in past ten years, 1.5 crore families have pledged gold to take loans from banks, and if unorganised sector money lending is included, one out of four families have mortgaged gold for loans.

"And this PM talks about mangalsutras and gold. A person who did not respect mangalsutra in his life is now expressing concern about mangalsutra," he said.'

b"RAIPUR: The curtains rung down for the second phase of Lok Sabha election campaigning in three constituencies of the state on Wednesday as Rajnandgaon, Mahasamund and Kanker Parliamentary seats go for polls on Friday. Polling at critical polling booths located in Maoist-affected Mohla Manpur, Kanker and Mahasamund regions will be held between 7 am to 3 pm, and voters in other polling booths will be able to cast votes till 6 pm.

Elections in 11 Lok Sabha constituencies of Chhattisgarh are being held in three phases. Bastar went to polls in the first phase on April 19 while polling on Rajanandgaon, Kanker (ST) and Mahasamund seats will be held in the second phase on April 26.

The poll officials said that 6,567 polling booths have been set up in the three constituencies and 458 of them have been categorized as critical polling booths. The poll timing for Mohla Manpur in Rajnandgaon, Antagarh, Bhanupratappur, Kanker and Keshkal in Kanker constituency and polling booth in Bindranawagarh in Mahasamund will witness voting from 7 am to 3 pm.

The remaining seven seats of Raipur, Durg, Bilaspur, Janjgir-Champa (SC), Korba, Surguja (ST) and Raigarh (ST) will go to polls in the third phase on May 7.

The contest in Lok Sabha seats for second phase saw an aggressive poll campaign both by BJP and Congress with leaders like PM Narendra Modi, Union home minister Amit Shah, Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath electioneering and the major parties levelling allegations of corruption, reservation on the basis of religion, unfulfilled poll promises upon each other. Modi and Shah accused Congress leaders of encouraging terrorism and Naxalism, and not attending consecration ceremony of Ram Lalla idol in Ayodhya. Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi highlighted its poll promises on caste census, Mahalaxmi Yojana and apprenticeship for youth.

Of the three seats Rajnandgaon constituency is the high profile seat with BJP's sitting MP Santosh Pandey contesting against former chief minister Bhupesh Baghel. In Mahasamund and Kanker, BJP has fielded Roopkumari Chaudhary and Bhojraj Nag while Congress has fielded former home minister Tamradwaj Sahu and Biresh Thakur, respectively.

According to poll officials, around 76 polling personnel for will be airlifted to nine polling booths in Kanker seat and 12 polling personnel for two booths in Mahasamund LS seat will be ferried to their destination in helicopters."

b'No Half Measures By Ruling Cong & BJP In Wooing Crucial OBC Voters | JD(S) Faces Battle Of Survival in 1st Phase Of LS Polls In StateCaste is complex. Caste politics, even more. The arithmetic of electoral politics may have eventually led Congress and BJP to employ strategies that don't upset the dominant caste groups' applecart both nationally and at the state level in these elections, but OBC voters are still being wooed, notwithstanding how fragmented their demographic distribution is.

Several months prior to the announcement of polling dates, Congress' clamour led by Rahul Gandhi and AICC president Mallikarjun Kharge for a nationwide caste census may have come close on the heels of the findings of a similar survey in Bihar becoming public, but action in Karnataka precedes that.

Much like with 'guarantees' this season, Karnataka has been at the forefront of the caste census, a report on which a commission headed by Jayaprakash Hegde -- who's now the Congress' candidate from Udupi-Chikmagalur -- has been accepted by the Siddaramaiah government. But he's yet to implement its recommendations.

Campaign plots of LS polls in Karnataka include the OCB narrative. If Siddaramaiah, with his Ahinda credentials, is Congress' lead actor, the BJP is projecting PM Narendra Modi as the OBC face.

Shivaraj Thangadagi, backward classes (BC) welfare minister, said, "Our government has done what none had before by accepting the report. Its implementation will not only benefit backward communities but also the party for sticking to its commitment. Concerns of other communities will be addressed while implementing this."

Union home minister Amit Shah and leader of opposition in the assembly R Ashoka have reiterated how BJP was with the OBCs, with Modi being "Sabse Bada (biggest) OBC" during their campaigns in Karnataka.

Nationally, Nitish Kumar -- who had commissioned the Bihar caste census -- leaving the INDIA bloc and Congress being concerned about caste matrices across states may have seen the grand old party use the OBC card cautiously, but it has included it in its national manifesto, while BJP continues to actively woo these communities.

"Congress didn't tolerate leaders from extremely backward classes. In 1987, Congress refused to accept Karpoori Thakur ji as opposition leader, whom we honoured a few days ago with Bharat Ratna. These days, Congress colleagues express concern about the number of people from backward classes in government and where they're positioned. But I'm surprised they don't notice the biggest OBC (referring to himself)," Modi told Parliament on Feb 5.

Modi, referring to himself as the biggest OBC, came close on the heels of Rahul claiming that the PM's Teli caste was not part of other backward classes.

Importance of Caste Census

India's first proper caste enumeration was under the British in 1931. Subsequently, while the constitution addressed education and job reservations for SCs and STs, the first independent govt realised there were numerous underprivileged backward communities, resulting in the Kaka Kalekar commission in 1953, which recommended a caste-wise census enumeration in the 1961 census.

But it was the Mandal Commis sion's 1980 report that proved pivotal, identifying 3,742 OBC communities and recommending 52% quotas, though only 27% reservations were implemented by VP Singh's government in 1989 amid violent protests and legal battles.

A landmark 1993 Supreme Court judgement (Indira Sawhney case) capped overall reservations at 50% but allowed exceptions. It also introduced the 'creamy layer' excluded from reservation based on annual income limits, currently Rs 8 lakh.

Karnataka Pioneers

In Karnataka, Mysore ruler Nalvadi Krishnaraja Wadiyar appointed the Leslie Miller Commission to examine non-Brahmin underrepresentation in 1918, despite opposition from then-Diwan M Visvesvaraya.

Post-independence, the Nagana Gowda Commission (1960) recommended 45% job and 50% education quotas for OBCs, excluding Lingayats, which prevented implementation. Then, the 1975 LG Havanur panel raised the quantum to 32% across the three categories it introduced. But the exclusion of Lingayats again caused friction.

To address this, the T Venkataswamy Commission was formed, which, in its 1986 report, included some Lingayat sub-castes, and again, in the 1990 O Chinnappa Reddy report, included Vokkaligas and Lingayats, who were dissatisfied with the representation. This finally led to the creation of a permanent BC commission. The first BC panel in 1994 was led by Kudur Narayana Pai.

And then in 2015, Siddaramaiah set up the H Kantharaju Commission to carry out a socio-economic educational survey, commonly called a caste census. While Siddaramaiah's tenure as CM ended before the report could be submitted, leaked contents from it created heartburn among Vokkaligas and Lingayats. Subsequent governments didn't accept the report, citing multiple reasons, including the technicality that the member secretary hadn't signed it. This prompted the Jayaprakash Hegde commission, which, using the Kantharaju panel's data, has submitted its report.'

b'Akhilesh.Singh@timesgroup.com

New Delhi: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's focus Tuesday on Congress's efforts to introduce quota for Muslims marks a significant escalation of BJP's "appeasement" charge against the opposition party.

PM fired the "Muslim quota" salvo while addressing a rally at Tonk-Sawai Madhopur in Rajasthan -- his last engagement in the state for Lok Sabha polls -- and said Congress has for long made separate efforts to implement Muslim quota despite the prohibition laid down on "Babasaheb Ambedkar's Constitution" on religion-based reservations.

The attack came even as Congress was still angrily protesting against PM's remark at Banswara, also in Rajasthan, on Sunday that Congress's pitch for "redistibution of assets" was part of a plan to take away assets from people and distribute among people who, going by his predecessor Manmohan Singh's 2006 speech at the National Development Council, can only be Muslims.

While Election Commission has started an inquiry into Congress's complaint that that Banswara speech was communal and, therefore, violative of the 'model code of conduct', PM Modi repeated the charge and rebutted Congress's protest about Singh's statement having been distorted, saying, "I was present at the meeting of the NDC."

Going by indications, the PM's consecutive volleys could be part of a larger offensive against the "equity" section of the Congress manifesto for allegedly seeking to create an opening for Muslims not just in jobs and education, but also in healthcare, public contracts, skill development, even sports -- something which might push the electoral contest from now on to the "secular-communal" terrain.

Highlighting extracts from the "equity" section of the Congress manifesto, BJP said that it implied Muslim reservation. "Point 3 of the Congress manifesto says 'encourage' minorities to take full advantage of opportunities but Point 6 says 'ensure' minorities receive 'fair share' on exactly the same issues as mentioned in Point 3," a senior BJP leader said and added, "if Congress manifesto had limited itself to just 'encourage', then it would have been OK. But how will Congress ensure? Such language is employed when the intent is to back the promise with legislative action."

Congress manifesto in "equity" section says that it will do socio-economic census (different from caste census) and then basis this it will strengthen affirmative action (Point 1). Same section also says in Point 2 that the 50% limit on reservations will be raised. "Read together, only one conclusion follows. Congress plans to install Muslim reservation -- not just in education and jobs but also in healthcare, public contracts, skill development, cultural activities and even sports?" the BJP leader said.

Congress in its manifesto in 2009 Lok Sabha polls had promised nationwide reservation for Muslims in jobs and education. The idea was to create a Muslim sub-quota within the 27% OBC quota. Although it could not be implemented due to legal hurdles but Congress in its manifesto in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls again mentioned that the UPA govt had taken steps to address the condition of backward Muslims by aiming to provide them reservation in educational institutions and govt jobs and further added, "We will pursue this matter closely in court to ensure that the policy is implemented through proper legislation".

The saffron party made a recall that Congress launched its pilot project to introduce Muslim quota in Andhra Pradesh after coming to power in 2004 when it made four attempts between 2004-10 to implement Muslim reservation. "Each time the Andhra HC/SC quashed the pernicious attempts of Congress. Unashamed, the UPA then tried the Muslim reservation at ventral level in 2011. Even this attempt was stalled by Andhra HC in2012 and SC agreed with HC," a BJP leader said.

In Karnataka, Congress promised to reinstate Muslim reservation that the BJP govt had scrapped. And finally in its 2024 manifesto, Congress talks of expanding affirmative action after socio-economic survey -- breach 50% limit set by courts and "ensure" Muslims receive their "fair share" in jobs, education and even sports.

"In UPA-1, Ranganath Mishra Commission recommended 10% reservation for Muslims, which Congress gave in Andhra despite being rejected by the high court. Congress removed all reservation of SC/ST OBC from AMU and Jamia Millia Islamia to provide for Muslims," said BJP spokesperson and Rajya Sabha MP Sudhanshu Trivedi.

He said in Kashmir, Congress never allowed SC/ST and OBCs to have reservation in representation on the pretext that it is a Muslim majority state and the Muslim Waqf Board by law became the biggest land owner after the Govt of India, due to successive Congress-led govts.'

b'NEW DELHI: Alleging that Prime Minister Narendra Modi wanted to end caste based reservations in the country, the Congress today asked him to clarify his stand on whether he was against the socio-economic caste based census in the country.

Addressing a press conference at the AICC headquarters here today, the party general secretary in charge of communications, Jairam Ramesh pointed out Modi government did not get the mandatory 2021 census done till now.

He pointed out the census is very important for the caste based reservations provided by the constitution. He alleged that Modi was deliberately avoiding the census since he wanted to abolish reservations in the country.

Jairam disclosed that during the UPA regime, a socio-economic caste census was done in 2011 to prepare the list of people living below poverty line, to make available authentic data about the population of SCs, STs and backward classes and to find out their socio-economic and educational conditions.

He said the Modi government did not publish the report, as he did not want the people of the country to know the details. He said the census was done following a detailed debate in the parliament as all the parties including the BJP wanted to get it done.

The Congress general secretary said, since the Modi government had not conducted the 2021 census, about ten crore people were being denied the benefit under the Food Security Act, which has been renamed as Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Anna Yojana.'

b'Nagpur: Congress' Rahul Gandhi slammed the BJP for using the OBC.

While addressing a rally at Sakoli in Bhandara, he said his party will order caste sensus if it comes to power. "Once the caste census is complete, "the truth will come out". "You are being fooled and this census will clarify your doubts.," Rahul said.

Most of Vidarbha has a sizable OBC population, which can swing elections either way.The Bhandara-Gondia Lok Sabha constituency is a straight fight between Congress and BJP, where both have fielded OBC candidates. Gandhi said even in the govt, representation of OBCs and other underprivileged communities is less.
