Modi and the BJP have denied political interference, with one senior party leader saying it was a "process of law" to take "appropriate action against corruption."

To counter the BJP, the opposition has formed a 27-member bloc -- the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, or INDIA.

But so far that alliance has proved lackluster, observers say. It has been beset by ideological differences, has seen a host of defections to the BJP and, even with the election in full swing, has yet to even name a prime ministerial candidate.

"What kind of a democracy can you have if you don't have a vibrant opposition, a robust opposition that can question the government?" asks Arati Jerath, an independent political commentator and journalist.

"That's why it's not really a question of whether Modi wins or not, it's a question of keeping the opposition alive to fight another day so that democracy in India survives."

'Scorched earth'

Among those leading the charge for the opposition alliance is Rahul Gandhi, longtime face of the Congress and the latest member of his family to bid for power.

He is the son of former Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. His grandmother Indira was India's first female leader, and his great-grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru, was the country's founding prime minister.

"If the BJP wins these fixed elections and changes the constitution, the country will be on fire. Remember this," Rahul Gandhi told the crowd in Delhi last month.

The BJP and its allies are gunning for a supermajority of more than two-thirds of the seats in India's parliament, the Lok Sabha. A rising fear among critics is that this would give the BJP the power to change India's constitution, which is rooted in the democratic principles of justice, liberty, equality and - crucially - secularism.

The BJP has repeatedly denied it has plans to change the constitution.

Congress party leader Rahul Gandhi speaks during a press conference in New Delhi on March 25, 2023. Money Sharma/AFP/Getty Images

"When I say that I have big plans, no one should be scared. I don't take decisions to scare or run over anyone, I take decisions for the wholesome development of the nation," Modi said in an interview with Indian news agency ANI earlier this week.

But the party has already begun publicly pulling India's government away from its secular foundation and leading BJP figures have openly advocated for the country to be declared a Hindu nation.

"There shouldn't be politics on the basis of religion in any country, they should talk about real issues. Until people's financial situation improves, there won't be any social reform," said voter Mohammad Irfan at the opposition rally in Delhi.

Opposition parties have found themselves facing a slew of legal and financial challenges in the run-up to this year's election.

Gandhi's Congress - the largest party in the INDIA alliance -- has accused the BJP of "tax terrorism" and crippling its ability to campaign after its accounts were frozen by the tax department, leaving it unable to use some $20 million in funds. It has also been landed with a $218 million tax bill.

Then came the arrest of Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi chief minister and head of the popular Aam Aadmi Party (AAP).

Kejriwal's detention on graft allegations came after the announcement of the general election last month, sparking protests in the capital. Analysts say it's the first time in post-independence history that an Indian chief minister has governed from behind bars.

Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal speaks during a protest against alleged attacks on federalism by the federal government, in New Delhi, India, on February 8, 2024. Altaf Qadri/AP

Kejriwal has denied the allegations, claiming they are politically motivated. He is just one of several prominent members of the opposition, including three other senior AAP leaders, that have also been arrested or investigated by state agencies in moves decried as political by their parties.

"I think there are very serious concerns about how free and fair the elections are going to be in India this time around," said Atishi, Delhi minister of education for the AAP, who goes by one name.

Reports have emerged of opposition party members being coerced into joining the BJP with the threat of arrest, while they were under investigation by state agencies. Other reports suggest politicians have had their probes dropped after switching sides.

Atishi said she was also approached to switch to the BJP. "Either you join the ruling party, and then the cases are closed or put into cold storage or if you don't, like the Aam Aadmi Party leaders, then the cases go ahead and you're arrested and put into jail," she said, without specifically naming who approached her.

CNN cannot independently confirm the incidents and has reached out to the BJP for comment.

In his interview with ANI, Modi denied any sliding of democracy under his rule and emphasized the independence of the Election Commission and state agencies such as the Enforcement Directorate, saying political leaders make up just 3% of cases.

"Shouldn't we let the ED work independently when it is supposed to do so?" he said. "I am convinced that corruption has destroyed the country. We should fight against corruption with our full strength."

Analyst Jerath said a BJP-led campaign to weaken the opposition was part of Modi's "scorched earth policy."

"Just wipe out whatever comes in your way so that this juggernaut can move on without any kind of challenge, without any obstruction," she said.

Gandhi 'not a contender'

Modi is enduringly popular, analysts say, appealing to both the poor and the affluent, especially among much of the roughly 80% of India's population who are Hindu.

During his 10 years in power, he has launched a raft of welfare policies including free food handouts, housing, cheap gas cylinders for women and infrastructure projects.

India is also the world's fastest-growing major economy and Modi's presence on the world stage -- including hosting the G20 -- has cemented the country as a modern global power, along with a history-making moon landing.

Author Christophe Jaffrelot told CNN Modi makes people feel "proud again of being Indian."

"There is a sense in India, a constant sense, of vulnerability, a lack of self-esteem. So to be recognized as a great power in spite of everything, (that) is attributed to him," he said.

That does not mean there aren't key issues the opposition could rally around, analysts say, including the BJP's failure to increase education opportunities or improve health infrastructure - especially following the coronavirus pandemic, which hit India especially hard.

Youth unemployment also remains a huge problem, close to 50% among 20-to-24-year-olds.

But the INDIA alliance has failed to capitalize on these weak spots, Jerath said.

"They haven't been able to weave together a cohesive kind of campaign, come up with a catchy slogan that will fire the imagination of the voting public," she said.

Congress leader Gandhi is one of the few opposition figures considered to have the kind of star power and name recognition to stand against Modi.

But though he may have the name, Gandhi lacks leadership skills, some analysts say.

Rasheed Kidwai, journalist and author of "24 Akbar Road," a history of the Congress party, said it's a winner-takes-all election and there is "no silver medal in politics."

"The problem with INDIA alliance is there is nobody who has that kind of hunger, who has that kind of personal(ity), who has that kind of inner sense of belonging or ownership to go in this election. Rahul is doing it but is not a contender," he said.

Gandhi recently completed a 6,713-kilometer (4,200-mile) walk across the country, starting in the violence-hit northeastern state of Manipur, to raise issues of poverty, unemployment, diversity and democracy with voters.

Despite these efforts, the BJP has dominated the campaign narrative.

A key gauge of opposition strength will be in those parts of India where the BJP has historically failed to make inroads.

Supporters of the All India Trinamool Congress (AITC) participate in an election campaign rally on Hill Cart Road in Siliguri, India, on April 16, 2024. Diptendu Dutta/NurPhoto/Getty Images

Regional opposition heavyweights, such as the West Bengal chief minister and All India Trinamool Congress head Mamata Banerjee and the south's Tamil Nadu chief minister Muthuvel Karunanidhi Stalin, will be vying to block a BJP takeover in their respective states.

But the only other major national party is the Congress, which has been the main opposition since 2014.

Congress governed the country for much of the 77 years since independence, and while it was once a powerful political force with its legacy rooted in the formation of modern India, it now finds itself in the doldrums, dogged by infighting and accusations of corruption within the party.

"In the Congress, the best and brightest are not fighting the election," Kidwai said.

Analysts say that during a decade in opposition, Congress has failed to rebuild its organization and political machinery to effectively take on the BJP.

The Congress organization has "decayed and almost died over the years, particularly in north India, and particularly in Uttar Pradesh, which is the largest, most populous state," Jerath said.

"There was a time after independence, and for many years after independence, that they used to say that you would find a Congress flag in every single village in India," she said. "That's no longer true."

Still, there is optimism from some.

The AAP's Atishi said that despite repeated attacks against her party, it has been able to defeat the BJP in Delhi again and again.

"Democracy becoming an autocracy ... That is what we are fighting against," she said. "I think that the people of India have always voted very sensibly, and we hope that they do so this time."

CNN's Kunal Sehgal, Aishwarya S. Iyer and Anna Coren contributed reporting.'

b'CNN --

Police in southern India are investigating a senior leader of the country's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) over a campaign video targeting Muslims, as critics accuse Prime Minister Narendra Modi of running an increasingly divisive election.

The police probe comes as the world's most populous nation votes in a mammoth weeks-long election in which Modi's Hindu-nationalist ruling party is widely expected to secure a rare third consecutive term.

The party has long denied being anti-Islam but opposition politicians and prominent Muslims have warned that its leaders have been deploying openly divisive rhetoric to turbo-charge their campaign.

According to a police report seen by CNN on Tuesday, Karnataka state police are investigating whether local BJP leader B. Y. Vijayendra and the unnamed holder of the party's official local X account "promoted enmity" between religious groups after the clip was posted online on May 4.

The 17-second animation depicts leaders of India's main opposition Congress party giving benefits to Muslims, alongside a caption in the local Kannada language: "Beware... Beware... Beware...!"

It shows caricatures of Congress's national leader Rahul Gandhi and its Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah feeding "funds" to a large bird wearing a Muslim skullcap, while giving nothing to three smaller birds portraying other marginalized minorities. The large bird then kicks the other birds out of their nest as the Congress politicians laugh.

The video was removed Wednesday after a request to X from India's Election Commission to take it down.

CNN has reached out to Vijayendra, the BJP and X for comment.

Critics said Congress' manifesto makes no mention of redistributing wealth to Muslims, while Congress lawmaker Manickam Tagore said the video was a "blatant demonization of minorities by ruling BJP," and urged the Election Commission to address its "divisive tactics."

Many of India's more than 200 million Muslims have expressed fear at the prospect of Modi's re-election, and critics said the video fits a pattern of openly Islamophobic rhetoric during the BJP's campaign.

Last month, the BJP's Instagram account published another animation that claimed the Congress planned to prioritize Muslims.

"If you are a non-Muslim, Congress will snatch your wealth and distribute it to Muslims," said a voiceover in the clip, which has since been removed from Instagram.

That video echoed similar comments by Modi, who sparked a row over hate speech last month while campaigning in BJP-ruled Rajasthan state, when he accused Muslims - who have been present in India for centuries - of being "infiltrators" who deliberately have large families to outgrow the majority Hindu population.

Modi's speech ignited widespread anger among Muslim leaders and opposition politicians and calls for election authorities to investigate. BJP party spokespeople subsequently said Modi was talking about undocumented migrants.

The election commission has asked the BJP to respond to the allegations.

In an interview with local broadcaster Times Now on Monday, Modi said the BJP is "not opposed to Islam and Muslims."

But many Muslims were skeptical.

"This is not a dogwhistle, this is a targeted, direct, brazen hate speech against a community," prominent Muslim journalist Rana Ayyub said in response to the speech.'

b'Benar\xc3\xa9s y Nueva Delhi (CNN) -- El primer ministro de la India, Narendra Modi, prometi\xc3\xb3 una vez en las elecciones que "vendr\xc3\xadan d\xc3\xadas buenos".

Para sus seguidores, se trata de la visi\xc3\xb3n de un futuro al alcance de la mano si Modi y su partido nacionalista hind\xc3\xba de derechas, el Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), consiguen un tercer mandato consecutivo en las elecciones nacionales de este mes.

En sus m\xc3\xadtines, decenas de miles de personas se congregan en una devoci\xc3\xb3n religiosa casi fren\xc3\xa9tica en apoyo de un hombre cuyas pol\xc3\xadticas, dicen, han transformado la vida de los indios de a pie y han ayudado a consagrar la incipiente promesa de movilidad social en un pa\xc3\xads todav\xc3\xada desgarrado por las divisiones entre castas.

Modi se presenta como un hombre de or\xc3\xadgenes humildes. Nacido como hijo de un vendedor de t\xc3\xa9 en una peque\xc3\xb1a ciudad de Gujarat, no encaja perfectamente en el modelo, a menudo de educaci\xc3\xb3n privada, decididamente metropolitano y angloparlante, establecido por muchos l\xc3\xadderes indios anteriores.

Modi, de 73 a\xc3\xb1os, es soltero, no tiene hijos y aparentemente reh\xc3\xbaye las posesiones materiales costosas en favor de un estilo de vida sencillo y asc\xc3\xa9tico.

Y aunque poco se sabe de Modi como hombre: su vida privada est\xc3\xa1 asiduamente protegida por un formidable equipo de relaciones p\xc3\xbablicas, su personalidad tiene resonancia en muchos.

Su ascenso pol\xc3\xadtico refleja en cierto modo la trayectoria de la India, que ha pasado de ser una naci\xc3\xb3n reci\xc3\xa9n independizada y liberada de los grilletes del colonialismo a convertirse en un pa\xc3\xads seguro y confiado que se acerca cada vez m\xc3\xa1s al estatus de superpotencia.

Modi, argumentan sus oponentes, ha hecho poco por apaciguar esas divisiones.

La persecuci\xc3\xb3n religiosa y la islamofobia han aumentado dr\xc3\xa1sticamente bajo su mandato, y muchos acusan al primer ministro de respaldar t\xc3\xa1citamente el sectarismo como medio de reforzar sus credenciales nacionalistas hind\xc3\xbaes, desviando al mismo tiempo la atenci\xc3\xb3n de los fracasos pol\xc3\xadticos, como el desempleo juvenil, que ahora se sit\xc3\xbaa cerca del 50% entre los j\xc3\xb3venes de 20 a 24 a\xc3\xb1os.

Entre las minor\xc3\xadas de la India, en particular los 230 millones de musulmanes del pa\xc3\xads, la perspectiva de otros cinco a\xc3\xb1os para un primer ministro que se llama a s\xc3\xad mismo "chowkidar" o vigilante, sigue siendo muy preocupante.

Muchos no creen que Modi vele por ellos, sino que los margina mientras cumple el sue\xc3\xb1o de su partido de transformar la India laica y pluralista en un Estado mayoritariamente hind\xc3\xba.

"En su camino hacia un tercer mandato, el primer ministro Modi se ha posicionado como sacerdote junto al jefe del sistema pol\xc3\xadtico... como protector de la naci\xc3\xb3n (y) como creador de una naci\xc3\xb3n hind\xc3\xba", afirma Saba Naqvi, autora de "The Saffron Storm: De Vajpayee a Modi".

Esta mezcla aparentemente potente y populista de empoderamiento econ\xc3\xb3mico y nacionalismo hind\xc3\xba ha demostrado ser una f\xc3\xb3rmula electoral de \xc3\xa9xito para Modi, al trastocar las antiguas l\xc3\xadneas de voto social y regional.

Seg\xc3\xban una investigaci\xc3\xb3n de Pew Research 2023, aproximadamente ocho de cada diez adultos indios tienen una opini\xc3\xb3n favorable de Modi, incluido un 55% que tiene una opini\xc3\xb3n muy favorable. Tales niveles de popularidad para un primer ministro en funciones durante dos mandatos desaf\xc3\xadan todas las convenciones modernas, tanto en la India como en gran parte del mundo democr\xc3\xa1tico.

"Ha hecho algo que no hab\xc3\xada ocurrido antes en la pol\xc3\xadtica india entre todos nuestros primeros ministros", dijo Naqvi. "Ha creado voluntariamente un culto a su propia personalidad".

Mientras el sol se pone por el Ganges, los devotos hind\xc3\xbaes se ba\xc3\xb1an en las aguas del r\xc3\xado sagrado y los sacerdotes ofrecen la oraci\xc3\xb3n diaria en sus orillas. Es aqu\xc3\xad, en la ciudad de Benar\xc3\xa9s, la circunscripci\xc3\xb3n electoral de Modi, donde el llamado culto a la personalidad est\xc3\xa1 en plena exhibici\xc3\xb3n.

Sin embargo, el presidente del BJP de la ciudad, Dileep Patel, que ha ayudado a Modi en sus tres campa\xc3\xb1as electorales, no se muestra sorprendido por sus niveles perdurables de popularidad. Para \xc3\xa9l, Modi representa el futuro de la India.

"Hoy la India es fuerte, capaz y autosuficiente bajo el liderazgo del primer ministro", afirm\xc3\xb3.

La biograf\xc3\xada oficial del partido de Modi cuenta la historia de un ni\xc3\xb1o pobre, el tercero de seis hermanos, cuyo padre era un "chaiwallah" o vendedor de t\xc3\xa9, que atend\xc3\xada a los clientes en la estaci\xc3\xb3n de tren local para mantener a su joven familia.

Y contrasta fuertemente con las generaciones de pol\xc3\xadticos indios de \xc3\xa9lite y urbanitas que hist\xc3\xb3ricamente han llegado a lo m\xc3\xa1s alto.

"Procede de un entorno pobre y eso le ayuda a entender al pueblo indio", afirm\xc3\xb3 Patel, presidente del BJP de Varanasi.

El primer primer ministro de la India, Jawaharlal Nehru, fue miembro del Congreso Nacional Indio, un partido pol\xc3\xadtico que fue fundamental para poner fin a casi 200 a\xc3\xb1os de dominio colonial brit\xc3\xa1nico. El rostro del actual Partido del Congreso, y principal oponente de Modi, es Rahul Gandhi, hijo de Rajiv y antiguo alumno de Cambridge y Harvard.

Modi, por el contrario, tuvo una educaci\xc3\xb3n modesta en la peque\xc3\xb1a ciudad de Vadnagar, lejos del ambiente pol\xc3\xadtico de la capital, Nueva Delhi, seg\xc3\xban Nilanjan Mukhopadhyay, autor de "Narendra Modi: The Man, The Times".

Se dedic\xc3\xb3 al RSS, nunca volvi\xc3\xb3 a casarse y aprendi\xc3\xb3 a "dejar todos los placeres de la vida", seg\xc3\xban una entrevista que concedi\xc3\xb3 en 2019.

En 1972, se hab\xc3\xada convertido en "pracharak" del RSS, seg\xc3\xban su biograf\xc3\xada, alguien designado para difundir su causa a trav\xc3\xa9s de reuniones y conferencias p\xc3\xbablicas.

Impuso el estado de emergencia, reforzando el control gubernamental, acorralando a los cr\xc3\xadticos, censurando a la oposici\xc3\xb3n y silenciando a la prensa.

Ajeno a las exigencias del matrimonio, Modi, que entonces ten\xc3\xada 25 a\xc3\xb1os, vio una oportunidad, seg\xc3\xban su biograf\xc3\xada. Se uni\xc3\xb3 a un movimiento para restaurar la democracia en la India, afirma su perfil, lo que marc\xc3\xb3 el inicio de su camino hacia los altos cargos pol\xc3\xadticos.

Y a falta de una vida familiar, muchos de sus seguidores lo consideran parte de la suya, lo que aumenta su atractivo como hombre corriente. "Modi es nuestra familia", dijo el tendero Jaiswal en Varanasi. "Todos somos su familia".

Modi se afili\xc3\xb3 al BJP en 1987, cuando este partido pol\xc3\xadtico marginal empez\xc3\xb3 a ganar adeptos impulsado por el auge del nacionalismo hind\xc3\xba en la India.

Considerado el brazo pol\xc3\xadtico del RSS, el BJP adquiri\xc3\xb3 relevancia en esa d\xc3\xa9cada cuando abog\xc3\xb3 por la destrucci\xc3\xb3n de Babri Masjid, una mezquita del siglo XVI que, seg\xc3\xban los hind\xc3\xbaes, se construy\xc3\xb3 en el lugar donde naci\xc3\xb3 Rama.

En 1992, los partidarios hind\xc3\xbaes de la l\xc3\xadnea dura, alentados por miembros del BJP, atacaron la mezquita, la destrozaron con sus manos y desencadenaron una ola de violencia sectaria que repercuti\xc3\xb3 en todo el pa\xc3\xads.

Uno de los fundadores del BJP, Lal Krishna Advani, al que muchos consideran el cerebro de la destrucci\xc3\xb3n de la mezquita, vio en Modi a un l\xc3\xadder, y le otorg\xc3\xb3 inmensas responsabilidades dentro del partido.

Ning\xc3\xban pol\xc3\xadtico "aporta la experiencia que tiene Modi", dijo Naqvi, la autora, el mes pasado desde su casa de Nueva Delhi, refiri\xc3\xa9ndose a sus diversos cargos pol\xc3\xadticos.

Modi prosper\xc3\xb3 bajo la direcci\xc3\xb3n de Advani, abri\xc3\xa9ndose camino en las filas del BJP. En 2001 fue nombrado ministro principal del rico estado de Gujarat.

Bajo el gobierno de Modi, el estado introdujo una oleada de infraestructuras, industria e innovaci\xc3\xb3n en su \xc3\xa1rido paisaje, convirtiendo el "modelo Gujarat" en sin\xc3\xb3nimo de desarrollo y eficacia gubernamental.

Su mandato no estuvo exento de pol\xc3\xa9mica.

La violencia estall\xc3\xb3 en Gujarat en 2002, cuando los hind\xc3\xbaes culparon a los musulmanes de incendiar un tren en un incidente en el que murieron decenas de peregrinos hind\xc3\xbaes, y buscaron venganza atacando viviendas y tiendas de propiedad musulmana.

Seg\xc3\xban cifras del gobierno, murieron m\xc3\xa1s de 1.000 personas, en su mayor\xc3\xada musulmanes. Los cr\xc3\xadticos acusaron a Modi de ser c\xc3\xb3mplice de la violencia, alegando que su administraci\xc3\xb3n no supo prevenir ni responder adecuadamente a los disturbios.

Tras los disturbios, Modi tuvo que hacer frente a las repercusiones internacionales: Estados Unidos le prohibi\xc3\xb3 la entrada en el pa\xc3\xads durante muchos a\xc3\xb1os por su preocupaci\xc3\xb3n por las violaciones de los derechos humanos.

Modi neg\xc3\xb3 con vehemencia haber cometido delito alguno y la Corte Suprema lo absolvi\xc3\xb3 de complicidad. Meses despu\xc3\xa9s de la violencia, fue reelegido con una mayor\xc3\xada aplastante, la "primera prueba" de su culto, seg\xc3\xban Naqvi, la autora.

Pero la polarizaci\xc3\xb3n de las comunidades dividi\xc3\xb3 profundamente a la naci\xc3\xb3n, dejando cicatrices que persisten hasta hoy.

El polit\xc3\xb3logo Christophe Jaffrelot sugiri\xc3\xb3 que los acontecimientos de Gujarat dieron m\xc3\xa1s confianza a los nacionalistas hind\xc3\xbaes. "Pero el propio Modi es tan inseguro que no puede enfrentarse a ninguna pregunta", afirm\xc3\xb3.

Modi abandon\xc3\xb3 una entrevista en 2007, cuando el periodista Karan Thapar le pregunt\xc3\xb3 por su papel en los disturbios de Gujarat. Rara vez concede entrevistas y no ha dado ninguna rueda de prensa en solitario desde que es primer ministro.

"No puede enfrentarse a un debate", afirm\xc3\xb3 Jaffrelot.

El "modelo de Gujarat" de Modi se hab\xc3\xada convertido en un modelo para la India y, en 2014, el BJP gan\xc3\xb3 por una amplia mayor\xc3\xada, aplastando al Congreso, la peor derrota del partido en sus m\xc3\xa1s de 100 a\xc3\xb1os de existencia.

Desde su llegada al poder, el gobierno de Modi ha modernizado la anticuada red de transportes del pa\xc3\xads, construyendo autopistas que conectan las peque\xc3\xb1as aldeas con las grandes ciudades. Su Gobierno ha construido nuevas centrales el\xc3\xa9ctricas y proyectos mar\xc3\xadtimos y, seg\xc3\xban declaraciones recientes del propio Modi, ha subvencionado la construcci\xc3\xb3n de unos 40 millones de viviendas de concreto para familias sin recursos.

El gobierno tambi\xc3\xa9n ha reforzado las capacidades militares del pa\xc3\xads. Y ha invertido dinero en deportes, ciencia y tecnolog\xc3\xada punta, lo que ha permitido a India prosperar en la escena mundial.

Pero para algunos observadores, tambi\xc3\xa9n ha surgido un patr\xc3\xb3n preocupante.

"Fue capaz de popularizar la pol\xc3\xadtica nacionalista hind\xc3\xba y su ideolog\xc3\xada", afirma Mukhopadhyay, escritor y bi\xc3\xb3grafo no oficial de Modi.

Modi nombr\xc3\xb3 a nacionalistas hind\xc3\xbaes para ocupar altos cargos en el gobierno, d\xc3\xa1ndoles el poder de hacer cambios dr\xc3\xa1sticos en la legislaci\xc3\xb3n, infundiendo una sensaci\xc3\xb3n de miedo entre los 230 millones de musulmanes que viven en el pa\xc3\xads.

En 2019, volvi\xc3\xb3 a arrasar en las urnas, esta vez con una propuesta m\xc3\xa1s claramente definida de supremac\xc3\xada hind\xc3\xba.

Derog\xc3\xb3 la autonom\xc3\xada especial de Cachemira, el \xc3\xbanico estado de mayor\xc3\xada musulmana de la India, y lo puso bajo el control directo de Nueva Delhi. Su gobierno aplic\xc3\xb3 una controvertida ley de ciudadan\xc3\xada que muchos consideran discriminatoria para los musulmanes.

Construy\xc3\xb3 el Templo Ram en Ayodhya, en el lugar donde estaba la mezquita destruida, reviviendo para muchos musulmanes los dolorosos recuerdos del derramamiento de sangre de 1992, pero aportando un sentimiento de orgullo a millones de devotos hind\xc3\xbaes.

Para sus cr\xc3\xadticos m\xc3\xa1s ac\xc3\xa9rrimos, la pol\xc3\xadtica econ\xc3\xb3mica de Modi tambi\xc3\xa9n es cuestionable. A pesar de que la econom\xc3\xada india crecer\xc3\xa1 un 7,3% este a\xc3\xb1o fiscal, la tasa m\xc3\xa1s alta de las principales econom\xc3\xadas mundiales, persisten las acusaciones de que Modi no ha creado suficientes puestos de trabajo ni ha salvado adecuadamente la brecha entre la clase multimillonaria del pa\xc3\xads y los m\xc3\xa1s empobrecidos.

"Ha hecho a los pobres m\xc3\xa1s pobres. Ha aumentado las desigualdades", dijo Jaffrelot, en referencia a la brecha de riqueza del pa\xc3\xads, que seg\xc3\xban un estudio reciente es m\xc3\xa1s desigual que durante la dominaci\xc3\xb3n brit\xc3\xa1nica.

En el frente diplom\xc3\xa1tico, se ha acercado a Estados Unidos, ha sido cortejado por Australia y el Reino Unido.

Al mismo tiempo, Modi ha mantenido la relaci\xc3\xb3n hist\xc3\xb3ricamente estrecha de la India con Rusia, adquiriendo enormes cantidades de petr\xc3\xb3leo de Mosc\xc3\xba a pesar de la invasi\xc3\xb3n de Ucrania, y mantiene relaciones tanto con Israel como con otros pa\xc3\xadses del Medio Oriente en un momento de creciente polarizaci\xc3\xb3n.

Y una abrumadora mayor\xc3\xada de indios parece respaldar su liderazgo. Una encuesta reciente de Morning Consult situaba a Modi como el l\xc3\xadder mundial m\xc3\xa1s popular, con un \xc3\xadndice de aprobaci\xc3\xb3n del 76% en su pa\xc3\xads.

"Es la figura n\xc3\xbamero uno en estos momentos. Es el \xc3\xbanico candidato a primer ministro", afirm\xc3\xb3 Naqvi.

En un mitin de Modi en la ciudad de Ghaziabad a principios de mes, miles de simpatizantes abarrotaron el gran recinto cuando subi\xc3\xb3 al escenario. Algunos iban vestidos como el dios indio Rama, otros de la cabeza a los pies vestidos de azafr\xc3\xa1n, el color oficial de su BJP, y sus gritos de triunfo retumbaban en el aire.

En la ciudad de Meerut, en el estado norte\xc3\xb1o de Uttar Pradesh, una seguidora de Modi dice que le vota porque es "distinto a cualquier otro pol\xc3\xadtico del mundo".

"Puse el p\xc3\xb3ster de Modi en la habitaci\xc3\xb3n de mi hijo", dijo Raniva, que tiene 36 a\xc3\xb1os y responde a un solo nombre. "De la forma en que (\xc3\xa9l) est\xc3\xa1 haciendo tanto por el pa\xc3\xads, espero que mi hijo tambi\xc3\xa9n haga un buen trabajo por el pa\xc3\xads".

En las calles de la capital, Nueva Delhi, la opini\xc3\xb3n est\xc3\xa1 m\xc3\xa1s dividida. "Hoy en d\xc3\xada hay muchos enfrentamientos entre hind\xc3\xbaes y musulmanes. Todos sabemos por qu\xc3\xa9", dijo un conductor de rickshaw sentado frente a la famosa mezquita Jama de la ciudad.

Ante la expectativa generalizada de que Modi gane c\xc3\xb3modamente las pr\xc3\xb3ximas elecciones, algunos analistas afirman tener verdaderos temores sobre el futuro de la democracia del pa\xc3\xads.

"Veo sin duda un deterioro de la calidad de la democracia en el pa\xc3\xads", afirma Mukhopadhyay. "Veo una mayor inseguridad y marginaci\xc3\xb3n de los musulmanes en la India. No es un panorama muy halag\xc3\xbce\xc3\xb1o. Pero es el camino probable que va a tomar la India".'

b'(CNN) -- Las elecciones m\xc3\xa1s grandes del mundo arrancar\xc3\xa1n la pr\xc3\xb3xima semana con la emisi\xc3\xb3n de los primeros votos en los gigantescos comicios nacionales de la India, considerados los m\xc3\xa1s importantes en d\xc3\xa9cadas y con el potencial de marcar el futuro del pa\xc3\xads.

Casi mil millones de personas pueden decidir si conceden al primer ministro Narendra Modi un tercer mandato consecutivo y prorrogan los 10 a\xc3\xb1os de gobierno de su Partido Bharatiya Janata (BJP).

Bajo el mandato de Modi, India se ha convertido en la gran econom\xc3\xada de m\xc3\xa1s r\xc3\xa1pido crecimiento del mundo, lo que ha llevado a este pa\xc3\xads de 1.400 millones de habitantes a convertirse casi en una superpotencia.

Pero la India tambi\xc3\xa9n se ha polarizado cada vez m\xc3\xa1s por motivos religiosos, y los cr\xc3\xadticos afirman que otro mandato de cinco a\xc3\xb1os dar\xc3\xa1 al derechista BJP de Modi un mandato para continuar con sus pol\xc3\xadticas, que han transformado el pa\xc3\xads de una rep\xc3\xbablica laica a una naci\xc3\xb3n hind\xc3\xba.

Esto es lo que hay que saber sobre las mayores elecciones de la historia de la humanidad:

Las elecciones nacionales de la India son un gigantesco ejercicio de democracia y log\xc3\xadstica que dura m\xc3\xa1s de un mes.

Pueden votar unos 968 millones de personas, m\xc3\xa1s que la poblaci\xc3\xb3n de Estados Unidos, la Uni\xc3\xb3n Europea y Rusia juntas.

Dado el tama\xc3\xb1o del electorado, no hay una fecha \xc3\xbanica en la que todo el mundo vaya a votar. Los comicios se desarrollar\xc3\xa1n en siete fases en todo el pa\xc3\xads, desde el 19 de abril hasta el 1 de junio. El recuento de los votos de los 28 estados y los ocho territorios de la Uni\xc3\xb3n se har\xc3\xa1 p\xc3\xbablico el 4 de junio.

Con arreglo al sistema multipartidista de mayor\xc3\xada relativa, los indios votar\xc3\xa1n para cubrir 543 de los 545 esca\xc3\xb1os de la c\xc3\xa1mara baja del parlamento, llamada Lok Sabha, y otros dos esca\xc3\xb1os ser\xc3\xa1n designados por el presidente del pa\xc3\xads.

El partido que obtenga la mayor\xc3\xada formar\xc3\xa1 gobierno y nombrar\xc3\xa1 primer ministro a uno de sus candidatos ganadores.

Modi y su BJP siguen siendo enormemente populares y se espera ampliamente que se asegure otros cinco a\xc3\xb1os en el poder.

Modi, de 73 a\xc3\xb1os, fue elegido primer ministro por primera vez en 2014 con una mayor\xc3\xada aplastante gracias a su pol\xc3\xadtica de desarrollo y lucha contra la corrupci\xc3\xb3n. Se le atribuye la implementaci\xc3\xb3n de reformas sociales y de bienestar, y se asegur\xc3\xb3 f\xc3\xa1cilmente un segundo mandato en 2019, esta vez sobre una plataforma m\xc3\xa1s aparente de nacionalismo hind\xc3\xba.

En esas elecciones, m\xc3\xa1s del 67% de los indios votaron, la mayor participaci\xc3\xb3n electoral de la historia del pa\xc3\xads.

El rival principal del BJP es el Congreso Nacional Indio, que ha gobernado el pa\xc3\xads durante gran parte de los 77 a\xc3\xb1os transcurridos desde la independencia, pero que ahora tiene baja popularidad.

En un esfuerzo por evitar otra victoria de Modi, el Congreso form\xc3\xb3 una alianza con otros l\xc3\xadderes de la oposici\xc3\xb3n, incluidos los principales partidos regionales. La Alianza Nacional para el Desarrollo Inclusivo de la India (INDIA) lanz\xc3\xb3 su campa\xc3\xb1a a finales del mes pasado con la plataforma de "salvar la democracia".

El v\xc3\xa1stago pol\xc3\xadtico Rahul Gandhi es la cara del partido del Congreso, pero otras figuras clave son el popular l\xc3\xadder del Partido Aam Aadmi y ministro principal de Delhi, Arvind Kejriwal.

Tambi\xc3\xa9n hay pesos pesados regionales, como la ministra principal de Bengala Occidental y miembro del Congreso Trinamool de toda la India, Mamata Banerjee, y el ministro principal de Tamil Nadu, Muthuvel Karunanidhi Stalin, que luchar\xc3\xa1n por impedir que el BJP se haga con el poder en sus respectivos estados, donde Modi a\xc3\xban no ha logrado abrirse paso.

El bloque INDIA se ha visto acosado por luchas internas y a\xc3\xban no ha presentado a su candidato a primer ministro. Los analistas afirman que tiene dificultades para igualar la calidad de estrella y el atractivo que proyecta Modi.

La oposici\xc3\xb3n tambi\xc3\xa9n se ve presionada por lo que considera una campa\xc3\xb1a del BJP para debilitar a los oponentes de Modi.

Varios miembros destacados de la oposici\xc3\xb3n, entre ellos el ministro principal de Delhi, Kejriwal, han sido detenidos o investigados por organismos estatales en acciones que sus partidos tachan de pol\xc3\xadticas. Las autoridades fiscales federales congelaron las cuentas bancarias del Congreso y le exigieron el pago de otros US$ 218 millones en impuestos.

El BJP ha negado injerencias pol\xc3\xadticas.

Entretanto, una nueva victoria de Modi consolidar\xc3\xada su posici\xc3\xb3n como uno de los l\xc3\xadderes m\xc3\xa1s importantes y longevos de la India.

El partido de Modi y sus aliados aspiran a obtener m\xc3\xa1s de 400 esca\xc3\xb1os en la Lok Sabha, lo que les dar\xc3\xada votos suficientes para cambiar la Constituci\xc3\xb3n de la naci\xc3\xb3n. Esa cifra tambi\xc3\xa9n mejorar\xc3\xa1 su mayor\xc3\xada absoluta asegurada en 2019, cuando el BJP obtuvo 303 esca\xc3\xb1os, frente a los 52 del partido del Congreso.

India es la mayor democracia del mundo, pero tras una d\xc3\xa9cada de gobierno del BJP, los analistas afirman que el populista Modi ha estrechado el cerco sobre sus instituciones democr\xc3\xa1ticas.

Las minor\xc3\xadas, especialmente los 200 millones de musulmanes del pa\xc3\xads, dicen que han sido perseguidas por las pol\xc3\xadticas nacionalistas hind\xc3\xbaes del BJP.

Modi ha sido acusado de silenciar a sus cr\xc3\xadticos y de reprimir a los medios de comunicaci\xc3\xb3n independientes de la India. En la Clasificaci\xc3\xb3n Mundial anual de la Libertad de Prensa, India cay\xc3\xb3 del puesto 140 en 2014 (el a\xc3\xb1o en que Modi lleg\xc3\xb3 al poder) al 161 de 180 naciones en la lista del a\xc3\xb1o pasado.

Desde la demolici\xc3\xb3n de monumentos isl\xc3\xa1micos hasta el cambio de nombre de ciudades fundadas por antiguos gobernantes musulmanes y la revisi\xc3\xb3n de los libros de texto de historia, el gobierno de Modi ha supuesto un cambio s\xc3\xadsmico para la India, que ha pasado de sus valores laicos fundacionales a los de una naci\xc3\xb3n en la que prima el hinduismo. Los analistas afirman que otro mandato del BJP empujar\xc3\xa1 a la India a\xc3\xban m\xc3\xa1s por este camino.

Los partidarios de Modi destacan su historial econ\xc3\xb3mico: India est\xc3\xa1 preparada para convertirse en una potencia del siglo XXI a medida que su econom\xc3\xada se expande r\xc3\xa1pidamente. Dicen que su presencia en la escena mundial, incluida la organizaci\xc3\xb3n del G20, ha consolidado al pa\xc3\xads como una potencia mundial moderna, junto con un alunizaje hist\xc3\xb3rico.

Modi tambi\xc3\xa9n ha cumplido muchas de sus promesas principales, siendo su mayor logro la inauguraci\xc3\xb3n del controvertido Ram Janmabhoomi Mandir, un templo hind\xc3\xba en la ciudad santa de Ayodhya que se construy\xc3\xb3 en el emplazamiento de la destruida mezquita de Babri.

Pero, aunque la econom\xc3\xada india est\xc3\xa1 en alza, el pa\xc3\xads m\xc3\xa1s poblado del mundo no ha logrado generar suficientes puestos de trabajo para los millones de j\xc3\xb3venes que luchan por incorporarse a la poblaci\xc3\xb3n activa. El desempleo entre los j\xc3\xb3venes de 20 a 24 a\xc3\xb1os alcanzaba un impactante 44,4% a finales de 2023.

En los \xc3\xbaltimos a\xc3\xb1os, los agricultores se han convertido en la mayor amenaza para el partido gobernante, y han salido a la calle en repetidas ocasiones para exigir una mayor protecci\xc3\xb3n de su bienestar econ\xc3\xb3mico, incluidos precios fijos m\xc3\xa1s altos para sus cosechas.

La agricultura es el principal medio de subsistencia de cerca del 55% de la poblaci\xc3\xb3n india, y los agricultores ya han conseguido presionar a Modi para que derogue pol\xc3\xadticas agr\xc3\xadcolas impopulares.

Se cree que las elecciones de la India son las m\xc3\xa1s caras del mundo, superando incluso a las presidenciales de Estados Unidos. En 2019, los partidos pol\xc3\xadticos, los candidatos y los organismos reguladores gastaron hasta US$ 8.600 millones, seg\xc3\xban el Centro de Estudios de los Medios de Comunicaci\xc3\xb3n, con sede en Delhi. Este a\xc3\xb1o, se espera que el gasto supere esa cifra.

Desde las altas cumbres del Himalaya hasta los remotos bosques de los estados centrales de la India, los votos se emiten electr\xc3\xb3nicamente en m\xc3\xa1s de un mill\xc3\xb3n de colegios electorales. Se desplegar\xc3\xa1n unos 15 millones de trabajadores electorales, que viajar\xc3\xa1n por carretera, barco, camello, tren y helic\xc3\xb3ptero para llegar a cada votante indio.

Con 4.650 metros de altitud, Tashigang, un pueblo situado en el extremo norte del estado de Himachal Pradesh, en la frontera con China, fue el colegio electoral m\xc3\xa1s alto del mundo cuando sus habitantes votaron en las elecciones al gobierno estatal de 2022.

En 2019, m\xc3\xa1s de 8.000 candidatos se presentaron a las elecciones. Este a\xc3\xb1o, todav\xc3\xada se est\xc3\xa1n anunciando los candidatos, pero m\xc3\xa1s de 2.700 partidos luchar\xc3\xa1n por los esca\xc3\xb1os de la Lok Sabha, incluidos seis partidos nacionales y m\xc3\xa1s de 70 estatales.

Cada partido tiene un s\xc3\xadmbolo que le asigna la Comisi\xc3\xb3n Electoral y que aparece en las papeletas, lo que ayuda a las decenas de partidos a diferenciarse, al tiempo que facilita a los votantes su elecci\xc3\xb3n en un pa\xc3\xads donde alrededor de una cuarta parte de la poblaci\xc3\xb3n es analfabeta.

Son objetos cotidianos como un ventilador de techo, un peine y un mango.

El s\xc3\xadmbolo del partido gobernante, el BJP, es un loto, mientras que el del partido del Congreso es una mano alzada con las palmas abiertas. El Partido Aam Aadmi de Kejriwal (o Partido del Hombre Com\xc3\xban) es una escoba, que representa sus or\xc3\xadgenes en un movimiento callejero contra la corrupci\xc3\xb3n.'

b'Rahul Gandhi stood in a red Jeep, amid a churning crowd in Varanasi, trying to unseat the Indian government with a microphone in his hand. "The mic isn't good," he said. "Please quiet down and listen." It was the morning of Feb. 17 -- Day 35 of a journey that began in the hills of Manipur, in India's northeast, and would end by the ocean in Mumbai, in mid-March. In total, Gandhi would cover 15 states and 4,100 miles, traveling across a country that once voted for his party, the Indian National Congress, almost by reflex. No longer, though. For a decade, the Congress Party has been so deep in the political wilderness, occupying fewer than a tenth of the seats in Parliament, that even its well-wishers wonder if Gandhi is merely the custodian of its end.

Gandhi called his expedition the Bharat Jodo Nyay Yatra -- roughly, the Unite India March for Justice. He never said it in so many words, but the yatra was an appeal to voters to deny Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party a third straight term in parliamentary elections starting on April 19. Congress, the only other party with a national presence, is the fulcrum of an anti-B.J.P. coalition. Indian pundits and journalists bicker about many things, but on this point they're unanimous: Only a miracle will halt the B.J.P. Still, it falls to Gandhi, steward of his enfeebled party, to try.

The speech lasted barely 15 minutes. Gandhi is a fidgety orator, unable to shrug off the routine disturbances of a rally. He kept calling for silence, and scolding overzealous policemen regulating the mob. He didn't ramble, exactly, but eddied around the point he wanted to make. "This is a country of love, not of hate," he said. He talked of two Indias, populated respectively by the millionaires and the impoverished. He laid into TV news channels, many of which have been captured by oligarchs prospering under the B.J.P.: "They won't show the farmers, or the workers or the poor," he said. "But they will show Narendra Modi 24 hours a day." Then he helped onto his Jeep a member of the audience, a young man who complained that, despite spending hundreds of thousands of rupees on his education, he still had no job. His is a common story in Modi's India. Two out of every five recent college graduates are out of work, and young people make up 83 percent of the unemployed. To his crowd, Gandhi called out: "These are the two issues facing India: unemployment and -- ?" He received only a tepid response of "poverty." When he finished, there was no applause.

The crush of people at the rally was suffocating, although in India a crowd is no index of popularity. People may gawk and then go vote for the other guy -- and Gandhi is, after all, one of the country's most recognizable men. Officially, he is no longer his party's president, but he is undoubtedly its face. At 53, with a well-salted beard and serious eyes, he's too old to be called Congress's "scion," but he still wears the sheen of dynasty. His great-grandfather, the unflinchingly secular Jawaharlal Nehru, was India's first prime minister. His grandmother, Indira, and his father, Rajiv, both became prime ministers; both were assassinated. His mother, Sonia, steered Congress into government in 2004 and 2009, but declined the top post. Then, on the heels of several corruption scandals, the mighty party -- 140 years old next year -- came unstuck. Out of 543 seats in the lower house of Parliament, Congress holds just 46, compared to the B.J.P.'s 288. Gandhi embodies all this history: the triumphs as well as the failures. For the crowds, that is the fascination he exerts.

One of Modi's successes has been not just to trounce the Congress Party but also to persuade people that the party has weakened India and emasculated its Hindus. Through his cult of personality, Modi is fulfilling a century-old project, recasting India as a Hindu nation, in which minorities, particularly Muslims, live at the sufferance of the majority. Emblematic of this is a new law offering fast-tracked citizenship to people fleeing Pakistan, Bangladesh or Afghanistan -- as long as they aren't Muslim. It is the B.J.P.'s totemic achievement: the use of religion to decide who can be called "Indian." Opposing this law or indeed resisting the B.J.P. in any way has proved difficult. Investigating agencies mount flimsy cases against critics of the government, as Amnesty International has frequently noted. (Amnesty itself halted its work in India in 2020, in the midst of what it later called an "incessant witch hunt" by the government.) Activists are regularly imprisoned, sometimes on the basis of planted evidence; journalists are sent to jail or otherwise bullied so frequently that India has slipped to 161st out of 180 countries in the World Press Freedom Index, just three spots above Russia. Pliant courts often endorse it all. Such is the mood in India that one of the plainest sentences in Congress's election manifesto is also one of its most resonant: "We promise you freedom from fear."'

b"Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party has never had the support of most voters. But his rivals are too fractured and dysfunctional to capitalize on that.

The last time Indians voted in a national election, in 2019, the Bharatiya Janata Party, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, won running away. But even then, more than 60 percent of voters cast ballots for other parties.

That Mr. Modi has established such dominance in Parliament despite falling well short of majority popular support is a reflection of a dysfunctional and fractured political opposition.

The main opposition party, the Indian National Congress, governed for decades after the country's independence in 1947, guided by the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty. The party's standing is now much reduced: In 2019, it won 52 seats in Parliament to the B.J.P.'s 303. It is not expected to do much better in this year's election, which began on Friday and runs for six weeks.

Here's why India's political opposition is in such dire straits.

The Congress is a shell of what it once was.

The Congress, long positioned at India's political center, has struggled to find a direction and offer an ideological alternative to the Hindu nationalist B.J.P. That has held back the broader opposition's fight against Mr. Modi.

The Congress has faced a leadership crisis, a series of rebellions and bouts of infighting. Even after two consecutive losses to Mr. Modi, the party has stuck to its dynastic leadership. It has again put forward Rahul Gandhi, the son, grandson and great-grandson of Indian prime ministers, as its face in taking on Mr. Modi."

b'But in March he joined several of his senior party leaders when he was arrested. He's denied corruption charges and accuses the government of being vindictive. Supporters fear his arrest will dent the AAP's election campaign.

What will decide how Indians vote? Will a grand new Hindu temple prove Mr Modi's trump card? Will the economy, job prospects or welfare schemes be uppermost in voters' minds? Or will they vote on the basis of caste or religion?

The temple to Hindu God Ram in the northern city of Ayodhya is expected to provide a divine push to Mr Modi's election pitch by appealing to the majority Hindu community.

The temple - which replaced a 16 Century mosque torn down by Hindu mobs in 1992, sparking riots in which nearly 2,000 people died, was inaugurated with much fanfare by the PM in January.

The event was broadcast live on TV; schools, colleges and most offices were given a day off and people were encouraged to watch the ceremony.

Could PM Modi's vow to make India "a developed nation by 2047", its independence centenary, chime with voters?

India - with its GDP at $3.7tn (\xc2\xa33bn) - is the world's fastest growing major economy. Last year, it beat the UK to become the fifth largest in the world and is on course to reach $7tn by 2027, which would see it leapfrog Japan and Germany into third spot after the US and China.

But the spoils of India's boom are concentrated in few hands and inequality remains high. India ranks 140th in terms of global per-capita income and more than 34 million of its citizens live on less than $2.15 a day, even though government data shows "extreme poverty" has reduced a lot.

Many voters will be thinking of jobs. Seven to eight million young Indians enter the labour market annually, but millions are unable to find work.

Recent government data shows falling unemployment and a steady increase in labour force participation - to 57.9% in 2022-23 from 49.8% five years earlier. But experts point out most new jobs are low-paying and poor quality - for example in agriculture or women doing unpaid family work.

A telling indication of distress is that millions more are now signing up for the $3-a-day government rural job scheme. Thousands are even ready to migrate to war zones for work.

They were meant to clean up murky political financing, but electoral bonds were recently banned by India's top court, which ruled them "unconstitutional". The court also ordered the government-run State Bank of India (SBI) to provide details of who bought them and how much parties received.

The fact that the BJP was the biggest beneficiary - securing almost half of bonds worth 120bn rupees ($1.4bn; \xc2\xa31.1bn) donated between 2018 and 2024 - isn't looking good on Mr Modi's report card.

Reports have linked many donations to companies being investigated by government anti-crime agencies. Calling it the "biggest scam in Indian history", opposition parties allege the agencies were used for "extortion", which ministers have denied.

The scale of India's welfare state is staggering: the Modi government claims it has spent hundreds of billions of dollars to help poor households, reaching more than 900 million people. A number of state leaders have also invested heavily in welfare schemes.

But does that free sack of rice or money to build toilets prompt people to vote for a party? Analysts say such schemes can help, but that they are unlikely to be the only driving factor.

India has long had religious divisions but critics say fault lines have deepened in the decade since the BJP won power. They say India is becoming a Hindu state where its secular status is increasingly being challenged and its 200 million Muslims - the country's biggest minority, accounting for some 14% of the population - are marginalised. The government rejects this, saying it is inclusive.

In the last Lok Sabha, the BJP did not have a single Muslim MP. Rights groups and activists also point to increasing violence against Muslims, especially in states governed by the BJP. The government denies accusations it has a divisive agenda and its supporters appear largely unconcerned by such criticisms.

The election comes amid accusations from the opposition, activists and global rights organisations that Indian democracy is under threat. Rahul Gandhi has accused the government of targeting opposition leaders, spying upon them and imposing constraints on parliament, the judiciary and the free press.

Organisations like Human Rights Watch say the Indian authorities have used politically motivated criminal charges, including terrorism, to jail many critics and foreign funding rules to harass the opposition, rights groups and the press - charges the government denies.'

b"Rahul Gandhi, a leader of the Congress party, submitted his nomination in Rae Bareli on Friday, shortly after declaring his candidacy in the important constituency. The party leader was accompanied by his sister and the general secretary of the Congress party, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, as well as Sonia Gandhi, the sitting MP of Rae Bareli.Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Friday filed his nomination from Rae Bareli, a few hours after announcing his candidature from the key constituency.

The party leader was accompanied by his sister and Congress party's general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra and Rae Bareli's sitting MP Sonia Gandhi.

The party has decided to drop Priyanka Gandhi Vadra this time around. Congress' loyalist KL Sharma will be contesting the Lok Sabha elections from Amethi, the seat Rahul Gandhi lost in the 2019 general elections to BJP leader Smriti Irani.

Friday was the last date for filing nominations for the seats that will go to polls on May 20 in the fifth round of the seven-phase general elections.

Also Read: Rahul Gandhi ditches contest against Smriti Irani, to file nomination from Rae Bareli; Congress fields KL Sharma from Amethi

Rae Bareli, the constituency was held by Sonia Gandhi who became a member of the Rajya Sabha.

The party has secured victory in the Congress stronghold in almost every Lok Sabha election since 1951. Prior to Sonia Gandhi, former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had been victorious in Rae Bareli on three occasions.

The constituency also chose Indira's husband and Congress leader Feroze Gandhi as its representative twice, in 1952 and 1957. Only twice has a member of the Nehru-Gandhi family refrained from contesting the seat, in 1962 and 1999.

Also Read: Rahul Gandhi has forgotten his own slogan 'Daro Mat': BJP slams Nehru-Gandhi scion for ditching Amethi

Both constituencies have been long-standing strongholds of the Gandhi-Nehru family, with family members representing these seats for many years.

The Congress, participating in 17 Lok Sabha seats in Uttar Pradesh through a seat-sharing agreement with the Samajwadi Party (SP), has declared candidates for all the seats.

Amethi is set to vote in the fifth phase on May 20, with the deadline for filing nominations set for May 3. Rahul's loss in Amethi, previously regarded as a stronghold for the Congress, to Smriti Irani in the 2019 elections was viewed as a major setback to the party's national reputation.

Also Read: Why Congress chose Rae Bareli for Rahul Gandhi

Rahul served as the representative of Amethi in the Lok Sabha from 2004 to 2019. His father, former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, was also a member of the Lower House representing Amethi from 1981 until his passing in 1991.

Sonia Gandhi ran for elections from this constituency in 1999 before handing over the responsibility to Rahul in 2004.

Currently, Rahul represents Wayanad in the Lok Sabha while Irani is seeking reelection in Amethi."
